It is much stiffer than I expected, armrest are too far away from chair even with their ability to slide in. Makes a squeak noise in the back support area. Hi Stu,  
I just received my Titan L today - with the PU leather option, rather than soft weave.  I moved up from a 17 year old knackered (nearly) office chair I inherited from my father - which was soft, leather affair with hardly any lumbar support and certainly fewer adjustable parts.

For context, I am used to using a ¬£700 Herman Miller Mirra 2 Triflex Chair at work, which are very comfy for long sits, but significantly more expensive  than most gaming chairs.

I was looking around for a decent chair while I am forced to work from home during the lock down, having developed a sore back sitting in my old 17 year old chair (which my kids now use!) and this had great reviews, including by those who use the same office chair as me, and compared it favourably.

I can't say I'm disappointed ! It might be expensive in comparison to a typical Staples or Ikea chair, but is of a much better build quality and I'll bet it'll last a lot longer too!

I'm happy with the comfort level, - it's worth noting that if  a chair is too soft it wont provide firm support. But that is an individual thing.

I love the adjust-ability of it, and found it a cinch to put together. Bit concerned about the dire warnings about fingers being trapped all over the box!

Already I can feel a huge difference to my back with the lumbar support, and it doesn't hurt that it can recline so well!

Finally a honest review, there are so many fake reviews about Secretlab chairs. I wanted to buy the Titan so I asked my colleague if I could borrow his Secretlab Titan for a few days, he was okay with that. To be honest I was really dissapointed with the Secretlab Titan, it looks great but it's NOT COMFORTABLE AT ALL!! It feels like sitting on a wooden chair. Thank you for posting an honest review. I bought the Omega and am really having a hard time trying to tell myself that I like it...but I am in more pain now than I was before buying it.  Honestly makes me not want to use my computer anymore
comment_reply: @Saahir RahamanThe seat itself was probably the easiest part to adjust to. I was surprised at how close it required me to keep my legs if I didn't want the pressure from the sides of the seat, but I hardly notice that now. The biggest issue is with the arm rest positioning, arm rest angle, and the shoulder positioning of the backrest. First off, the armrests on this chair are very hard. I see sponsored reviews where people try to claim they are soft and comfortable... They're not. I am 31 years old, so I am just starting to notice when things hurt, and these arm rests hurt. They are positioned far back on the chair, and even with the 4D movement and spacial adjustments you can make under the chair, they still seem very far back on the chair. The biggest issue I have with them is the angle they are at when the chair is locked at an upright sitting position. No matter how I adjust them, I am having either constant pain in my forearm or constant pain in my shoulder, elbow, and hand. These are clear signs of carpal tunnel syndrome, as well as issues with the radial and ulnar nerves, all of which I had no clear issues with until I bought this chair. To give you an idea of size, I am 5'8" and about 170lbs, which falls within the range of the Omega chair... However I find that I feel too big for the chair.

I'd like to point out that when you get into a driver seat of a well made car, the seats are typically firm. Definitely not plushy like a lounge chair, or a couch. This is for the exact reason this chair is likely made firm, it provides much better support for long sitting durations. I've driven a cross Canada/US roadtrip that had me in the car for 9-10 hours a day for 1.5 weeks, and never had back pain or comfort issues, despite the seat being fairly firm.
Ordered mine the other day, I‚Äôm done useing computers / office chairs. They only last me two, or three years then I‚Äôm buying a new one. My back is killing me looking for something that will last!

comment_reply: Michael, it is a great chair.  It is firm, but not in an uncomfortable way.  I am 6'1" tall and 200lbs without any extra padding on me and the chair is a pleasure to sit in.  I occasionally watch a movie in my office, and the recline (back) and tilt (seat) are a nice feature.  The fully adjustable arm rests are also high enough to rest you elbows on and type comfortably with keyboard on top of a standard height desk.  I haven't adjusted the lumbar again since I got it, and I think it is quite supportive.  I hope this helps.

comment:
The genius of this chair is that it goes against what you think comfort is. I've been plagued by back problems my entire life, compounded by a spinal injury several years ago. Any length of time spent at my desk would result in both back pain and what I call "chair fatigue". 

After a month of using it I had NO back pain. None. Not a bit and chair fatigue was non existant. I can sit in that thing for 12 hours plus and I just don't get tired. And this is no fan boying. I've owned so many chairs that I've lost count and they all failed me in some way. But this chair just keeps on giving. 

I love it and my wife loves it. Not only is a delight for her to sit in after a long shift caring for sick and elderly patients but it's genuinely made her a happier person. And I have to admit it made me a happier, more relaxed and less irratible person as well. 

This chair may not give you what you 'think' you want, but it certainly gives you what you need. Gone are the days paying for back treatments, painkillers and any sort of cushion to make a cheaper chair feel comfortable enough to use for prolonged periods. 

Also they are built like tanks. After several months of use the chair looks and feels as good as the day I got it. 

I set up a computer in another room and bought myself a cheaper chair that looked similar. And that was all that was similar. Within days my back was complaining, the arm rests just weren't right and I was napping during the day just to take a rest from sitting. So today I put together a new one and I don't regret a penny I've spent on either of the Titans we now own. Yes it is expensive, but how much am I going to save on back pain treatments? How much sanity will I save now I'm relaxed and my relationship has improved. I know it's crazy to say and probably more crazy to read, but it's the truth. 

Now as to cost. I think of it this way. How long do we spend in bed each day? Now think how much you would spend on your bed. Now take into account that sitting is one of the worst things to do to your back and, for me, the calculation is simple. My back deserves this chair. And if you are invested in your own back lasting the duration of your life then maybe, just maybe you deserve it too.
comment_reply: I like the outlook that it gives you what you need,not what you "think" you need. I ordered mine like 3 weeks ago and cant wait for it to arrive. I currently have a GT racing chair I got off amazon for like 150$ and it's okay but I'm looking for the long term investment. Thanks for your input I really appreciate it

comment: This is a solid enough review but it certainly does show the damage that cheap office/gaming chair makers have done to the overall market. Most folks who go out to buy some kind of desk/office/gaming chair to use at their computer will not do a ton of research and will only really see the rather cheap and poorly built options in the $100 to $250 range. This has created a misunderstanding since many potential chair shoppers are going to see that price range as "normal" without considering the compromises made to build quality to reach that price point. Those that do dig into it a bit and do some research will find that there are a metric ton of really cheap, generally disposable chairs and a handful of companies making really expensive, really high-end chairs. These high-end chairs end up running into the $1000+ range pretty easily and are simply not practical for a lot of consumers. Sadly, this chair sits in a unpleasant position since it is generally really well built and is priced rather reasonably (relatively speaking) but it also isn't going to show up at a place like Staples, Best Buy, or even Ikea. People who are looking for that "best bang for the buck" option are going to have a hard time finding out that this thing exists and that is a shame.

comment: I recieved my Secretlabs Omega Chair two days ago. After sitting on cheap chairs all my life and burning through average office chairs who go for about 80-150 euros, the Omega really holds up in terms of quality. I too imaged it would be softer, but in the end its the firmness and stability that gets you through the day sitting. In my day to day job i also sit most of the time, so my work chair isnt super comfy, but not unpleasent either - but my ass won't hurt when i sit on there for at least 8 hours 5 days a week. And thats the same feeling and support i get from the Omega. It's build like a tank and to last, which was also a consideration on my part - because i dont like to buy shit every goddamn two years. And Stu, i stumbled on your channel by accident and i have to agree with your regulars: Please narrate a documentary, you have a nice voice.

If you want a chair to help with back pain then any racing chair is a terrible choice. 95% of them have 0 lumbar support apart from an included cushion which is a joke. The "built in" lumbar support within this particular chair looks like a mosquito bite. I highly doubt it offers any ergonomic support at all. I always advice people to fork out ¬£850 on a new Steelcase/Herman Miller chair. It will last for a decade and the warranty will cover almost anything. This thing will be torn to bits within 3 years, guaranteed. All the key components of these chairs come out of the same factory in china, nothing is specifically designed, its all off the shelf sub-par quality stuff.
I bought the 2020 Secret Lab Omega Soft Weave last summer and it is the best purchase I have ever made. üëåüèº
comment_reply: mlb shark The seat padding is indeed harder than an average ‚Äògaming chair‚Äô but they are designed like that for longevity. They do ‚Äòbreak in‚Äô slightly but I find my chair THE most comfortable I have ever had. It actually promotes you to sit up straight with proper posture unlike the cheaper gaming style chairs.....

I bought a Titan a couple months ago, wish I hadn't. It's like sitting on concrete. The seat is so hard it makes my butt numb after a couple of hours, and the backrest is rock solid also and makes my back hurt. The inbuilt lumbar support is no better, being positioned far too high.
No qualms about the build quality though, it's built like a tank. I emailed Secretlab and had a whinge and they sent me a free lumbar pillow which has made the backrest far more comfortable. But given how expensive this chair is it shouldn't be causing me pain.
Very regretful purchase.

I've had a Titan 2020 SoftWeave for 2 days now.  I agree after sitting in it that it's really uncomfortably firm.  The front end of the seat is even harder and digs slightly into my legs.  The lumbar makes creaking noises when I move around in the seat.  The chair tilt doesn't seem good for rocking, because rocking forward causes a hard abrupt stop and it doesn't bounce back.  I wish the pillow had more give, and the armrests don't go back far enough.

Edit: after two weeks, I can say that the seat is a lot more comfortable than it was initially.  It's still pretty firm, though.  Also the creaking lumbar is apparently a defect and Secret Lab said they'd ship a replacement, which makes me feel better.

comment:
I don't really get the hate over the warranty thing. They get free exposure and costumers get free 2 extra years of warranty, it's a win/win and the secretlab can use the money they saved on advertising to improve their chairs. It's a company, of course it wants to make money and save money.
 
I do have the chair as well, and I completely agree with me expecting it to be much softer than it is BUT.. i had a high quality soft chair before and after just couple of years all those soft parts were sat through and hard as a rock.  I have a feeling that this hard padding will last much longer and my ass actually got used to it by now. And as a tall person with a long ass spine, i love the lumbar support, not to mention most of the other chairs on the market don't really fit very tall people. By being so firm the chair kind of forces your body to maintain a healthy shape. 

But yeah, would be nice if they kicked the price down to about 300 eur i think.


Can you buy better chairs? Absolutely, if you want top tier chairs look at say Herman Miller, their stuff is significantly better than chairs like the Titan, and they only cost about ten times more, so it's a great deal. Seriously tho, I think titan is overhyped but a decent value for the price (unlike Dx Racer which is crap in my opinion, their quality control is a joke) but if you can afford to go really high end then get something like the Herman Miller. If not, then you won't make mistake with the Titan, or Omega, etc, just make sure you are expecting a good chair, not a godlike chair for your money.
comment_reply: Win/Win? I won't buy it.. they win then? :)

comment: Thank you for an honest review on this chair everyone else lies about this chair and says that it's the best chair ever because they get sent it for free to review. But finally an honest review out there (and the reason I know it's honest is because I personally own this chair) and everything you mention is definitely true. The chair is stiff not super comfortable. Yes very good for the back though with the lumbar support. But after sitting in this chair for several hours I definitely have to get up and walk around for a bit also the arm rests are pretty bad and while you can adjust them they aren't padded at all. Overall it's not a bad chair but it's definitely not worth the $400 price tag.
comment_reply: I find it extremely comfortable.  However, I'm coming from a sunken in folding lawn chair to this, and that thing demolished my back.  I absolutely need that stiffer support.  But its definitely not for everyone.  If one is looking for a softer feeling, they should look elsewhere.

comment:
I bought a SoftWeave Omega chair recently and I like the adjust ability and quality of build. My only downside to the chair is:  IT IS HARD AS A ROCK.
On a scale of 0 -10 soft(0) to hard(10)  this chair is a 9.5 on the scale.   I would have liked some soft in it. Now you know.

I bought the Titan around two weeks ago and not saying this because I paid $394 US for the chair I'm going to say it because it has helped me a lot already. I'm disabled with a very bad back, I sit at my computer pretty much 8 to 10 hrs a day. The Titan is the most comfortable chair I've found to date and I've spent a little over $2000 US over the last 3 years or so trying to find something that didn't make me want to scream. The Titan is very firm to sit in but it does conform to you while at the same time supporting all the right parts. It's also large enough for someone like myself who's right at 6 foot and 276 pounds, Ya I know I'm an old fat man but that's okay. As far as quality if you've bought so called office chairs or gaming chairs in the quantity that I have you would be impressed by it. Watching you try to build yours was actual torture, why in the hell did you try that balancing act to get the back on instead of sitting the chair base flat on the box it shipped in to have it up a little bit and then quite easily slide the back into position? I guess my knowing to do that comes from the sheer number of these style of chairs I've built over the years. I didn't notice the relief cuts on the bottom of mine as you did on yours but I'm sure they're probably there as it's common practice in automotive seats to cut that type of relief so the fabric doesn't stretch and tear in the corners. The Hog Rings as they are called are widely used in Upholstery and quite common, if used correctly like on the Titan you'll notice that inside that fabric loop they're going into there is a metal rod that the fabric has been folded over and then double stitched into place. That type of anchoring system will literally last for decades or until the fabric has completely broken down. Look under the seat in your car or truck when you get a chance and I'm betting they are used there as well. These chairs are designed after Automotive Seats and made much in the same way. The Cold Molded Foam of the seat base is also something that's used in high quality auto seats as it lasts for years and never becomes squishy as other less dense cheaper foam does. I'm looking forward to using mine for years and not having to continually be in more pain than needed or having to spend more money to buy lesser quality chairs. I was tired of buying chairs for $100 to $200 US only to have them be uncomfortable or simply break down and fall apart, so I figured why the hell not just spend the money and get something that would last.
   Anyway this is all subjective but I spent around a year researching, watching reviews and reading them. I found that they're overwhelmingly positive as in stupidly so, this chair and Secret Labs as a whole has between a 98 to 99% positive review rating which is unheard of for a product of this type. Not even the top dogs can make that claim. I hope you continue to enjoy yours as I will mine and thank you for an honest open video of your opinions and feelings about the chair. The fact you've found it helps you has re-enforced what I've found/felt and it isn't just in my head because I spent so damned much money, LOL...
(I know this is a book of a comment so thank you for humoring an old man).
comment_reply: @Justin Buritica how does this make sense?  He could certainly have been deciding a month ago, and either ordered it two weeks ago and received it last week, or ordered it 3 weeks ago and received it two weeks ago.

comment: This is bizarre, because I had that exact same standard-issue leather office chair you had prior to setting up your Titan, and it finally bit the dust last week.  Just received and setup my Secretlab chair over the weekend.  Loving every minute of it.  Great review here.

To answer your question at 04:46, because I have the Aeron and I hate so much that the back doesn't support my head and neck. Other than that it's amazing, but since I sit on my desk more than 10 hrs a day I need something bigger and more supporting.

My workplace uses the Herman Miller Aeron chairs....I am not a fan.  I developed knee pain after only a few months of work, which I believe was due to the design of the chair bottom.  I was only 22 at the time and haven't had the pain ever since refusing to use the Aeron chair (35 now).  It is entirely possible I needed a small sized chair and my office only orders medium and large, but I'm not about to ask management to special order a $1,000 chair that I might end up hating when I already have one that works fine.

On a side note, one of our satellite offices uses the less expensive Herman Miller Celle chairs, which I find much more comfortable than the pricier Aeron's.

comment:
Everyone at my workplace sits on Aerons. I have been using one for about 2 years.
Is it a good chair? Absolutely, it's comfortable, and adjustable in _almost_ every way, the mesh material breathes, the build quality is extraordinary, and there's a 12 year warranty.

Would I buy it? Hahahahahaha... absolutely not, it's imho overpriced as hell. I'm not in the chair design and manufacturing business, but I find it very hard to justify that price tag. Maybe making a chair that good costs this much, but I doubt it.

What's my gripe with "gaming" chairs? Well _most_ of them are just plain garbage, because they're not really adjustable, and have zero lumbar support. The Secretlab Titan is one of the exceptions, having lumbar support, but its height is not adjustable, which concerns me (I'm about 5'5" or 168cm tall, and the Titan is meant for 175cm and up).

I have the Herman and miller chair







And it‚Äôs not that great
Got my titan a couple of days ago. Best buy for my back!
People keep telling me to get a HM Aeron, but it's because you can get them for ¬£250 used on eBay, but does that also come with Wotsit fingers rubbed on the edges? I dunno.

So, I am an Aeron chair owner watching your video :P Since you seem to be interested in why someone who owns one would watch your video, I'll give you some background. I'm a gamer and occasional streamer whose job is teaching remote IT classes, so my job and most of my hobbies revolve around sitting in a chair for 12+ hours a day. People spend a crapton of money on things like furniture, clothes, decorations, alcohol that give you nothing tangible long-term. That's fine. An uncomfortable chair however gives you something very tangible; back pain. The Aeron solved that issue for me. However, I'm considering a SecretLab Titan XL for my game room as it speaks to the nerd in me more.

First, the reason why a lot of people recommend the Aeron chair is because it's used commonly in the office space by a great many companies and the people who work at these types of companies (and likely get to use these chairs at work) can't afford them at home and are looking for the next best thing. Your 5/10 however is not the kind of review that tells me (and likely anyone else) that it's anywhere close however, so people recommended a jump in quality/cost. A lot of people commented recommending it because they assume that you must make enough money to buy one if you're popular enough of an influencer that Secret Labs is asking you to shill (which I'm glad you didn't).


Second, the seat and back of an Aeron aren't made of cloth. They're this weird mesh weave stuff; think of it like a hammock, only more comfortable. Because they don't use fabric, they don't really collect smells or moisture the same way cloth does. These chairs are so often used in the workplace that you can frequently get them very cheap; I've seen some as cheap as $300 with all the bells and whistles and they can be a hell of a lot easier to find right now during covid. I can't get a Titan XL for the life of me right now. Anyway, for leather and stuff with this mesh weave style, I would personally feel comfortable getting it used. A chair with fabric though? No way in hell.

Regardless, your review sounds promising as a possible secondary chair as the way the back is shaped definitely suits my chair and your chair well. You didn't change your 5/10 rating in this followup, so I'm curious what you would rate this chair today and is it still holding up over a year out?

I am looking into a SecertLabs chair myself and this is where my contention is. I have an Aeron at work and love it, it works great and I can find used ones for around $400. However I like the styling and general aesthetic more from SecretLabs, but I'm worried about the support/comfort.

I think the reason you saw so many Aeron comments is because you can find a used one usually around $400. They are excellent chairs and last 10-15 years easy. I used to work in an Operations Center where we had 24/7 coverage and the workers union required Aeron chairs for all of the employees. It was for good reason, those things are VERY comfortable and super adjustable to all sizes and needs. 

Thanks for and unbiased review and for giving me more to think about.

Been enjoying my secret lab titan also. 40 hrs a week for three months so far. I usually have it upright and forward for a good posture during work and recline slightly during breaks or light work. My pu 2.0 looks brand new still. Only wear is the elbow rest, but it may just need a wipe down. Some wear on the wheels, rolling off the hard plastic floor mat and cutting on the edge.

Mine last around 1 year and 9ish months before leather began stripping, now I get to experience the fun of picking up fake leather off the floor for the next few months until I throw it away. PU Leather sucks, if youre gonna get this chair get the Soft Fabric.

Not lying here but I didn‚Äôt expect something soft, I really wanted something firm but not too hard. I just received my Titan XL yesterday, and my first sit down, I actually bounced a bit. Keep in mind I kinda let myself plop down on it. Now, I‚Äôm a big guy, tall and wide. I gamed all night, about 8-9 hours and I experienced no pain whatsoever. Usually I can only handle 3-4 hours max of gaming at anytime because of how much other chairs hurt me. This chair though was like a dream come true and I have rarely ever been more proud in a purchase that I‚Äôve made. 

Is it for every big person out there? Well I guess that comes down to personal preference if you prefer soft or firm. This chair however, if it makes any sense at all is a bit of both but more so on the supportive side. It‚Äôs more than I could ever have  hoped for. 

I hate giving in to hype, not very often are things worth the hype or the price. With this chair though, I believe, in my honest opinion that it is worth it‚Äôs hype and price. I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs at peak price/performance.

So I have had that Herman Miller chair for 7 years now for work and it's been a solid chair but pricy. Good ventilation but not worth the price.  I then purchased a 2018 Secret Lab Titan 2018 chair for gaming specifically.  Was so much better I use it for work as well and now I just pre-ordered the Titan Cyber Punk edition (I liked the colors ok!)  Titan is much better chair and the head support is built in. For the Herman Miller you have to pay around 200 US or so for the head rest so now the chair is 1200. I didn't get the headrest. For the money, Secret Lab is much better and well worth the money. 1 year of use no issues with Secret Lab. 7 years of use on Herman Miller no issues either. But for comfort and functionality I would definitely go the Secret Lab route. Definitely get the leather. I'm just not a fan of fabric chairs. But thats a personal preference.

Love the review, I was already deliberating between the Titan and an HM Aeron for home working when I stumbled across your channel. I gotta call you out on the Aeron fanboy criticism though, based on real life experience. I work in an industry where operators sit at consoles for up to 18 hours a shift. The chairs themselves are shared, in constant 24/7 use, and get absolutely abused by the users. Since switching to Aerons about a decade ago nearly everyone has fallen in love with them for the comfort and lack of back pain - in fact our H&S people don't like operators sitting on anything else for long shifts. The office staff get plain old office chairs and finding an "ex ops" Aeron to steal for the office is like gold dust! The "grannies tights" mesh is fantastic at keeping you cool and letting "bodily vapours" dissipate. It's the only chair I'd consider buying second hand as a result, as it doesn't have a stinky foam core to absorb all that yuck. I have no idea how good the 12-year aeron warrany is, but I see plenty of 10+ year old ones floating around in regular use still (you can tell they are older by the different lumbar support). 

All of that considered, I'm probably still going to buy a Titan softweave - because I like how it looks and I find the price & colourways of the Aeron a bit stiff for home use. 2nd hand ones are good value but rarely in any colour other than black. I'll still be glad to sit on an Aeron when I get back to work though.

Hey Stu, great review! I wanted to give my 2 cents to the aeron thing. Also, wanted to give you a bit more perspective on where all these people are coming from. The thing is, most people are extremely apprehensive about anything labelled as "gaming" (myself included). This tag is often used in a way that aims to milk out as much as possible from a very big and lucrative market and resulting in cheap and mostly not-very-durable things being shipped out in expensive and glittery packaging. A wide variety of stuff like "gaming headsets", gaming this gaming that, have flooded the market which are mostly subpar in quality at best. Most gaming chairs are not an exception. Anyone saying aeron is worth it, is not lying or has been paid by herman miller to do so. I have these in my office and I don't think I've ever sat on a more comfortable chair in my life. These are not old people chair. The complete changeover from sitting on a cushion to a mesh changes everything you remember about sitting on an office chair. It feels like sitting on those folding beach chairs with extremely soft cloth where you just sink in but still feel fully secure and supported. Now since ive been working from home, I miss these TERRIBLY. I have been looking at slightly cheaper alternatives as these make a HUGE dent in the pocket for sure (US$1200 for me). Someone suggested me secret labs omega so i started digging about this company. So far so good. Although, I will be keeping an eye out for a deal on aeron as someone in my discord was able to get a pretty sweet deal on a brand new aeron ($600) with their local seller. I'd say if you can afford it, go for aeron. The only drawback I see with aeron is a lack of headrest which is fairly important for me in a gaming chair.

I think the primary reason why people enjoy the aeron and similar office chairs is because they are usually quite cheap as refurbished chairs and have a vast network of spare parts available. Therefore you could in theory use the same chair for decades and exchange parts that may wear down. Looks shouldn't really be your main concern either, it should simply be down to how comfortable you feel in it. There are plenty of brands other than Herman Miller that also produce office chairs constructed with ergonomics in mind. None of these companies have yet landed on the racing bucket seat for a product. Therefore people are very sceptic about this approach. It all comes down to if you trust the office chair companies who have existed for 50+ years or the gaming chair company who all source the same parts from one manufacturer in China and slap their own branding on it.
I was impressed that you can buy parts from them.   If you can buy every replacement part including the seat and back it will save tons of money over buying another chair in a few years.

I bought an Omega early 2019, cost just under 600 AUD shipped. Before it even arrived I felt like I had made a bad decision at that price.
But when it arrived, oh boy. Firm, solid and quiet. The packaging alone was amazing. I fell asleep in it reclined on the third day. My back has never felt better and posture trained itself without me putting any thought into it. I will admit, the side bolsters on the seat seemed a bit too firm in the beginning, but I guess my ass was used to sitting in pillows for years, and after a couple of days I didnt even notice it anymore. 
I've used it daily for about 16 or so months now and the leather has not peeled or cracked anywhere. The stitching is still the same as day one. The only damage is on a back corner from me spinning into my desk constantly. and the armrests have loosened up a fair bit due to me using them too much.  
Loved it so much I bought my son the Stealth Edition June 2019 which is a revised version of mine with better armrests. Probably going to pick up the Cyberpunk Edition next week, I mean everyone needs multiple SecretLabs chairs right?

comment: I doubt Herman Miller is that worried about Secret Lab. They're a pretty big supplier for companies, which is why they're so much more expensive - they're meant for much tougher use than a regular consumer chair. (Think places like call centers or offices with round-the-clock shifts.) I wouldn't be surprised if the people pushing the Aeron worked somewhere that had them. I worked at a larger company that used them for their ergonomic option. Looks aside, the chair was pretty highly regarded when it came out because of its ergonomics. They're not very comfortable in my opinion, though. Plus that knit mesh tends to sand through your clothes over time.

Yo, got my Titan back in September 2018. They've made upgrades since then to this chair from my understanding. The plastic arms of the chair (the one holding the armrests) are wobbly as hell, pretty much in a very very negative way. The soft rubbery parts of the armrests (where the arms lie) is torn on the right one. This was due to fairly heavy use and squishing them to check firmness over a long period of time. Pillow's soft rubber strap is basically done, but I was touching it often as it was satisfyingly soft. Chair itself has no peeling yet, and I am from Texas where my room and outside temps can get pretty high. Almost 2 years of use and only a little bit of cleaning in all this time, it's still looking pretty cool overall. I have the all black PU version. 

There is some wear and tear, but the main body of the chair is doing fantastic for the heavy usage I've put it through. I have to agree with most of the things in this review, especially the money part. Unless I landed a job with a solid salary of around $100k USD per/yr, this is about as much as I'm spending on a chair. This is a good chair, not the absolute greatest, but a solid choice in the market where you shouldn't really feel bad about buying. 

Definitely one of the more stylish options.

I use my chair about 10-12 hours every day for both work and after work gaming sessions. I have spent 1.000 ¬£ on an ergonomic office chair before and have never been so disapointed on spending that kind of money on anything. These chairs have no headrest and generaly they will start hurting after a few hours of sitting in them simply because they force you to sit up straight all the time and you can't really relax in them.
I own a Perseus ADJ chair for 2 years now (https://www.adjbenelux.com/adj-perseus-gaming-chair-black-red.html) and it is a massive improvement on the ergonomic chair that costed 5x the price of the one I own. Quality wise, yeah OK, it's a 200¬£ chair and after 2 years the rubber armrests are starting to give in and the foam in the seat is starting to wear down. But I never regreted changing from expensive ergonomic seat to a (much cheaper) gaming seat.  The comfort of use by being able to rest your head against something just far outways the 'perfect' seating position of an ergonomic chair if you sit in it for more than a few hours.
I am 100% considering a Secretlab chair. I don't like very soft seating anyway, so that would be no issue for me. And if it lasts for around 5 years for the price of 426 EUR / 388 ¬£ (current price for a Softweave fabric Titan 2020)...I would consider that a very good deal. And they look very nice too. I'll watch some more video reviews before buying one, but so far all the reviews I've seen are ranging between possitive with one or two afterthoughts and 'best chair I ever used'. I'll probably take my chances on that for a bit less than 400 ¬£.

I like how the 1,099 pound chair has 4/5 stars on that website.  If I ever spent that much money on a chair, it damn well better be a perfect 5 out of 5.  As to why everyone on the internet says to buy one, I think it's because a) they're obscenely comfortable -- I sat in a used one and it was more comfortable than any chair I've ever been in, I just didn't feel comfortable spending $400-500 on a refurbished product; b) you can get them refurbished for around the same cost as this chair; and c) based on how good that ancient used one I sat on still looked and held up, they last way, way, way longer than any chair that's cheaper.
I will absolutely get one when I'm rich enough to spend a new bed's worth of money on a chair.  I really should, considering I spend equal amounts of time in both.

The reason ppl recommend that Herman Miller chair is that it‚Äôs a professional office chair designed for 8+ hrs of sitting in and working. + It‚Äôs built like a tank, and has one of if not the most adjustable sitting positions. Now I don‚Äôt own this chair and I‚Äôm sure not everyone that hyped it does. But a friend of mine does, and I‚Äôve sat in it for extended periods of time, and can attest to its quality. I also happened to have ordered, and now own a Secret Labs Titan XL Softweave Charcoal Blue (which came with a damaged base, that I‚Äôm now waiting for a replacement). So I‚Äôm not really biased or shilling for Herman Miller, but it is the top of its class, and if you have the money, definitely worth every penny. I wish I could afford it, but decked out with a head rest, in the US that thing is over $1200 (X-chair makes a decent knock-off version of the Herman Miller, but it‚Äôs not the same. Nor cheap either). I don‚Äôt get the hate for people that tout that Herman Miller, the reason they recommended it specifically to  you is that you state in your review that the chair is primarily for working in; that Herman Miller is a spot on recommend for that use case.

Although the price of the Aeron (and other chairs like it) is extreme, there are plenty of reasons why they are the top of the line. Now whether or not they actually justify the price, that's another question and in my own opinion, they don't. However they're made more for businesses than the ordinary consumer as they know the vast majority of people will just buy normal everyday chairs, not high end ergonomics and therefore they don't need to worry about pricing as much and can afford a premium price tag as big businesses will invest in them for their employees if needed. It's the same as any business oriented products. Is the standard person going to buy a 5000 dollar graphics card for a pc that isn't even good at running video games? God no. But businesses that need them for data analysis, scientific modelling or extensive real time rendering will easily fork out that money. 
.
Chairs like the Leap, Aeron, Embody and so forth are considered the best for a reason and are in many ways a superior chair to the Titan. However at three times the price, the price/performance may be a lot worse. I do agree though that people coming in basically bragging about their great high end chairs is stupid and either they're wanting to just show off their chair or knowledge or they got one, weren't happy with it and now go to other reviews of cooler looking chairs to put them down trying to make themselves feel better. 
.
All this said though, your notion of second hand chairs being nasty make no sense. You sit on buses, trains and planes. You sit in other people's cars, in used cars, on other people's furniture and chairs, in waiting rooms, in classrooms as a kid or in college, in office chairs in work and all of these have one thing in common usually...they've had many other people sometimes hundreds, thousands or millions of people sitting on them, farting and whatever else. But you don't care about them? It's a stupid argument and completely illogical. You can also steam clean them or clean them with whatever best suits the material or buy refurbished which have had that done to it previously though at an extra cost.
.
Anywho, the titan seems like a pretty cool chair but there is a reason that it's the price it is when compared to the others. It definitely looks the best by a mile. It's not even close. The thing is like a throne. But there are technological advances in certain high end chairs that make it a bit more understandable as to why they're the price they are, even if they look rather plain or like a normal everyday chair you'd buy for 50 quid. And at the end of the day, no one chair is suited for every person and a lot of it is subjective but THAT is the very reason why some high end chairs such as a Steelcase gesture or leap are so beloved. They're some of the only ACTUALLY ergonomic chairs available that allow you to adjust nearly everything on the chair to get yourself in the exact position you need to be in for your maximum comfort. Most chairs do not allow this and that's one feature the Titan cannot match.
comment_reply: @Stu‚Äôs Reviews Ah I see. Even still though, toilets and things like that are just as bad often even in our own homes but I see your point. That said though, a lot of used models are actually from businesses that are upgrading etc. but I guess it depends on where the source is coming from which may not always be possible to verify.

Thanks for the honest, down to earth review. And thanks for not starting the review with "Hey guy's, what's up?" and doing away with the infuriating heavy rock soundtrack that so many think is necessary. 

As someone who has suffered bad lower back pain for decades, rather than years, I'm slightly surprised at your disappointment of the firmness. Medics, aka those who know better than I do, have told me for as long as I remember that a soft seat is far worse than a firm one, so it makes sense that a firmer chair would be better for our backs. I would also say that like many people I have bought pillows, massagers, oinments and creams, physio treatments and all sort of gadgets for pain relief, extending well into 4 figures, I don';t think it's expensive at all. I've also seem and bought chairs costing up to ¬£250 which have been total crap. 

I also like the idea of the additional 2 year guarantee for a recommendation, in a world where everyone you buy from online expects you to fill in a survey in your time for absolutely nothing in return it's a refreshing change. It's hard in a world of what sometimes feels like almost infinite competition. Even worse are the firms that are charging you an extra hundred quid for an extra two years warranty, and at least it shows that Secretlabs have enough confidence in their product to make the offer. 

At 5'6" and 175 pounds I'll probably go for the ¬£329 Omega, and if it helps my back even 20% and helps me do more as a result it will pay for itself in any event. Your review has helped a lot.

I have this identical chair, in the same material and color, and about the same age (delivered 9/6/19). I agree that it's much firmer than I expected, and I was initially disappointed too. For a while I put a memory foam seat cushion on it, but I've since removed that and decided to just get used to the firmness. Mostly it has been fine, but I do wish there was a bit more cushion in the bottom. Like you, I really appreciate the firmness of the back - that part is remarkably comfortable even after a very long day in the chair (8 hours working, then 4 hours gaming or browsing).

I've removed the arm rests, because even at their lowest setting, they were too tall for me, and when my arms were resting on them, my shoulders were hunched up - it caused me some shoulder and neck pain, so I removed them. It's nice that they can be easily unbolted.

My chair has also gotten creakier than it was. It still feels very solid, it's not falling apart or anything, but now when I shift in it, the back makes squeaking noises that it didn't when it was new.

Overall, I agree with your evaluation. I still wish the bottom was just a little softer though.

comment: Quality review. I have occasional back troubles, don't need a new chair right now. But I'll definitely be referencing this review later on.

Agreed and I love my Titan chair. I have the HM aeron and work and i definitely prefer mine than works. Also the $995USD Aeron price tag is only the base model with almost 0 adjustability. Want additional back support? $95. Tilt limiter and seat angle? $100. Fully adjustable arms? $205. Wheels for hard floors? $50. A different color besides black? $100+. All of a sudden this $1000 chair is over $1500

I personally had an issue with a new chair where the foam had a permanent indent in it on the top of the chair (this issue was probably from the way it was boxed as it was there when the i unpacked it) but I contacted Secretlab and they had me take a couple of photos and replaced the back with a new one no issue at all. They were great to deal with and sent out the replacement part within 2 weeks if the issue being raised.
mine feels like it‚Äôs pushing me forward and sliding off

Risking a good old lambast here, but I have a 2nd hand Aeron (bought in Australia for $800 AUD which is equivalent of about 25 quid). It's a  great chair, but is it the best chair of all time? 

Not really, I would never use it at home when chilling at the PC, but I like having it at the office. The arms are super annoying (they constantly, slowly drop down about 2-3 times over the course of a working day, and they flap around a bunch when simply using them normally), the actual wheels / frame kind of jank around when you move (it's mostly fine when you're still) and the adjustments are nonsensical. The quality of nan's mesh is really good, it's soft but solid. The reason it's so expensive is it's made in the USA. 

I'm currently using the Neuechair by Secretlab, which is actually trash. I sold my Omega and bought it thinking it would be actually good, but it's garbage. The mesh is so soft you kind of sink into it and the lumbar support is painful. 

Right now I'm trying to track down a Steelcase Leap because it has another cult following like the Aeron. Unfortunately no one has them for sale used in Australia and buying them through a dealer is $1,300+. Has anyone here tried the Leap V2?

Secret Labs does state on their website that they make their chairs firm because its better for your posture. I will admit I was surprised by how firm it was, but after only a few minutes in the chair, I  thought the $400 was worth it. I've had mine a couple months now and so far, no problems and no regrets.

Found this video looking for reviews of the Titan and I think this video might have sold me on it more than any others that I have found. Alot of the reason the gaming chairs seem to be such a polarizing topic to chair enthusiasts? is the overall design/ergonomics.  The ergonomics of the gaming chairs seem to be lacking real lumbar support, highly cushioned seats or armrest adjustments that are not only commonplace but frequently discussed features of higher end office chairs.  To each their own but ive found that the used market for these high end chairs to be worth the potential downsides, I bought a used steelcase v2 for under 200usd that to my inspection (including smell) was like new and will likely be my office chair for the next 8 years because it still is under warranty for that long.

I was looking at used areon's and Steel series Leap chairs and the areon"s seemed to hold up better parts wise in most regards but the leap was more comfortable for me even more so than the embody.  There are plenty of reasonable alternatives online tho like the ergochair or one i tried that i honestly thought was better than any of the others was a 400$ the "workpro 1200" from office depot. In reality "race car" style seats if you can call them that were not designed too hold your body in a healthy position for extended periods (Laman's 24hr race car seat's show how different a seat designed for that task would be). The side effects of prolonged poor posture are slow to build up and like developing unequal muscle groups when body building; very hard to correct later. 
I can only ask anyone looking for a chair too maybe give the boring, lame looking, & seemingly expensive office chair a try they may surprise you

comment: nice click bait

Had my Secret Lab Titan Ash since last December 2019. Been going well and the chair is still in good condition. My girlfriend got the Softweave version and also, the chair's condition seems quite good!
I've also bought myself a DXRacer King series back in 2016 and while I love that chair too, the leather is starting to wear now. However, I do find it slightly more comfortable than the Secret Lab Titan. Unfortunately, ever since the mounting of that chair, it makes a lot of bad noise whenever I sit on its lowest level... like, a lot of cracking sounds. The Titan chair from SL is very silent compared to it.
Another plus with the DXRacer King would be the two cushions given with it. One for the neck and another one for the lower back. I find these more comfortable than the Titan's.
Overall, they're both good chairs and I do look forward to see how the Titan will fare in a few years about it's wear and possible tear, compared to the DXRacer King.

Even if you're fine with used chairs, the only reason people say to buy Herman Miller used is to defend the absurd price.  Of course, it's completely ridiculous to compare cost value of a used product verses a new product.  And ultimately when you WAY overpay to buy a used Herman Miller chair that potentially has issues or something is broken... you won't have a warranty and they'll still blame you for picking the "wrong" used chair.  I feel like these shills just want to feel better about the poor return on value decision they made.

Frankly, I don't even care that a chair labeled for "gaming" or even what it looks like.  I want something of decent quality, that reclines, and maybe even includes super high-tech features... like a head rest. /s  Why pay more for less features that I want?

I got the HM Aaron via work and it crippled me. The mesh seat base is terrible for your SI joints and sacrum as it squeezes them together in a pincer motion with your coccyx in the inevitable ravine your ass makes with the weight all concentrated in the centre. Months of physio and then eventually I mentioned the brand of chair to my physio and he rolled his eyes and explained the idiocy of mesh seat chairs. Also learnt that immediate soft comfort is your enemy it needs to be firm which will do you a world of good long term. Better no pain after hours of being at desk than the 10 second "oh this is soft" followed by years of being played with back pain and hundreds on physiotherapist...

comment: Quality review. Thank you for being upfront about your bias and finding somebody who had gone through the warranty process. I really can't express how valuable and reassuring that is after having other painful warranty experiences.

I bought a softweave omega and had issues out the box, the tilt mechanism was pitted and missing coating, the wheelbase was also pitted and scratched. I contacted secretlab and had a response within 12 hours, they sent me both parts immediately, I told them that I was disappointed with the chair coming damaged when they have an inspected sticker on them but I am very pleased the ease of the claim process. I will be buying another omega for my son.

I'm actually watching this review because I'm trying to choose between the Titan and the Steelcase Gesture. Or the Steelcase Leap.

And, yes, Steelcase are 1000 dollar chairs. If you do your research there's a reason people recommend them & Herman Miller... It's not shilling, people are just getting very serious and cork sniffy with their chairs now. Think of any enthusiast market where people buy into the high end equipment. Vinyl records, guitars, headphones, etc... High end materials, for sure, but the necessity is debatable. 

Personally, I still don't know what to get. The Titan does seem a bit low quality for the price. The Gesture is more than I want to pay. And I'm with you, I would never buy a used chair. No way. But it's hard for me to accept that a gaming chair isn't just... junk. People pay 1000 for a new mattress every couple of years, a chair seems like a better investment. These gaming chairs all come out of the same factory.

If I could get a new Steelcase for around 800 I'd be very tempted, but I'd be sweating the whole time during checkout. There's also the Autonomous Ergochair2, which tries to provide a Steelcase/Herman Miller style chair at a cheap price... But the price definitely reflects the reviews, usually with the seat cushion being the weak link. I'd be interested in seeing your review on the Ergochair2. It's cheaper than the Titan.

Right now the Steelcase Gesture is my top pick, but I really do wish I could find something more affordable. The Ergochair2 is a contender, but the reviews all seem fake. The Titan seems like the best gaming chair, sturdy and all, but it's still a gaming chair and not designed for ergonomics... The chair market is obnoxiously frustrating. I've pretty much thrown my hands up in the air at this point. I just want to move on from OfficeDepot chairs, they're pure rubbish. I'm currently sitting in an Ikea Markus and it's terrible.
comment_reply: Get the Leap. I've got a Steelcase Please V2 myself and would have got the Leap if I could find it for the right price, but ended up going with this. I'm in love with it.

comment: I love that chair.
I have the same Secret Labs Leather Titan. It is literally the best chair I have ever purchased. I agree 100% with the opinions and quality in this video.

Softweave is good.
Don't bother with PU leather.
I have a Secretlab and the PU started peeling after 9 months. They replaced it for $50. But if I could, I would have gone back and gotten a Softweave.
And that's what I'll be doing in a year's time, when this replacement PU begins to peel again.

My office has HM Aeron chairs and I bought the Titan a month ago and I prefer the Titan. I'm 190cm and I find the lumbar support for the Aeron pokes into my hips and is really uncomfortable and not supportive. The Titan is better in this regard, for me at least. I find the Titan a bit wobbly when you raise the seat up high though, which is probably my biggest gripe.

Thought I'd chime in here. I have had my PU leather Titan 2020 since January and I did have to deal with customer support. I send them that my backrest was feeling somewhat 'off'. They responded rather quickly and when I provided them with a picture and a video showing some squeaking, like some parts were moving individually they immediately recognized that it was faulty and send me a new backrest for free.
Personally I love the ass rest for it's firmness. Overall it's a good chair. I love the functionality of the 5D armrests (although beware, I've read some comments online that the inner mechanisms are made of plastic so I wonder how they will hold up as time goes by). However, the arm rests, due to the functionality are somewhat wobbly, so if you are a gamer that mostly rests both arms on the armrest this wobbling can get annoying in certain positions. 
Keep in mind though like with many things the prize premium you pay does not directly correlate with the quality you get. A 400eu chair is not 4 times as good as an Ikea 100eu chair. Initially this did disappoint me somewhat as I also expected it to be more like a cloud. I have also read a lot of differing claims of things awry, ranging from the tilting mechanism, to the seat part's sagging down to the backrest individual parts shifting up, so keep that in mind.
The +2 years warranty for sharing it on social media is despicable though

Ive been a SecretLab titan owner since October . Like you syu, I was caught off guard by how firm the chair was . Little did I know that the chair  firmness ,along with the built in lumbar support would be a back saver . It‚Äôs hard to have bad posture while sitting on the secretlab titan chair . If anyone is going to invest on one of these chairs , fork over a little more money for the titan version of the chair . You‚Äôll thank me .

comment: I wholeheartedly agree that second-hand chairs are nasty... Hell I don't even like to think about the cleanliness of MY chair let alone one owned by some other bloke
comment_reply: This makes absolutely zero sense. When you're in school, you sit on chairs that hundreds of people have used day in, day out. When you sit in college, same deal. When you sit on a chair in work, half the time it will be a chair that many others have sat on in the past. Same goes for sitting on the bus, sitting in a waiting room, going to a friends house and sitting on their furniture. Hell when you sit on your own damn furniture, other people from your own family have been sitting and farting on it. What about toilets? Every time you use your toilet, someone else from your family or your boyfriend/girlfriend etc. has sat on it and done their business numerous times. Public toilets (which I'm not a fan of myself) are even worse yet you've probably used them. Also any kind of bacteria or virus that could possibly be present will be long dead by the time you get your chair and set it up. If that's not enough, you can steam clean them or use whatever cleaning supplies that are best for the material of the chair. This idea of them being nasty is completely irrational and illogical.

comment: I wholeheartedly agree that second-hand chairs are nasty... Hell I don't even like to think about the cleanliness of MY chair let alone one owned by some other bloke
comment_reply:
Most second hand chairs can be fitted with new upholstery. So the entire frame is second-hand, which is fine since that can be cleaned with a damp cloth, while the upholstery, which is more difficult to clean, is brand new.

The frame of those chairs is build to last. I also have a refurbished desk, the frame is older but the top is brand new. And it's the frame that is expensive if you want things like height adjustable.

So usually the comparison is between one of the newer high-end gaming chairs or a refurbished office chair (that is usually 1000 dollars/euro) with new upholstery.

So, my girlfriend's dad works at an office and they upgraded their chairs, so we acquired a (used) Herman Miller Aeron Chair. I had no idea it was such an expensive chair until I went online and saw the price of it (which is shocking) and I have been chair shopping for a while now because I absolutely hate this Herman Miller chair. Let me tell you, if you are over 6' tall and you are bigger body type, the Herman Miller chair is NOT for you. It is extremely uncomfortable if you have a long torso. It is unbearably short in the back so you have no support in your upper body.. The depiction you showed of what a spine looks like in a short backed chair is absolutely how I feel when I'm in this chair.  As a big guy at 6'4" 280lbs and someone who ends up sitting at a desk a lot, this review was very helpful as I am vacillating still on what to purchase. Definitely a helpful review and to hear that someone as tall as you have enjoyed the Titan model and not the XL has made me hopeful that this chair may be what I'm looking for. Thanks!
comment_reply: Looking forward to it! Thanks again.

Just to clear the air about Herman Miller. It's about long term investment. In the long run a Herman Miller will last much longer than a secret lab chair or any gaming chair for that matter. The Herman Miller will come with a 12 year warranty. It's like buying a mattress, if you spend a good portion of your life sleeping it's probably better to spend a good amount of money on a good matrress. Same goes for a chair if you work from home or spend a lot of time in a chair. $1000 is very reasonable for the length of time the chair will last and the comfort. Mesh might look odd at first but is vastly superior in my opinion to leather or cloth due to it being more breathable. At the end of the day it's your money so your choice but don't write off a very good chair because of a high initial price tag without exploring why there is that price.

Gotta say your review has been thorough and well done . Bravo ( I like a firm chair )

I don't own an Aeron but I have sat in one 8 hours a day in the office for the past 5 years and I can attest it is a remarkable chair. It is by no means a super comfy chair but I was never uncomfortable in it even when I was on it hours on end. In fact, I didn't know how much it costs until I looked it up. It is definitely in a different price range than SecretLab products, but the quality is remarkable. The chair I was using was at least 10-12 years old and it still works as it should with minimal wear.

I‚Äòve gotten mine a few weeks back an can totally confirm that it is quite firm, but not as firm as I expected it to be after seeing your initial review. It‚Äôs actually more comfortable to sit in for long hours because of this ‚Äúbalanced firmness‚Äù and - like in your case - it‚Äôs relieved my back-pain. It‚Äôs not gone, but A LOT better. Something to keep in mind if you‚Äôre thinking about getting this chair and are a guitarist (or bassist) thinking about getting this to record in: the armrest are quite large and will require you to sit on the first half of the seat to properly hold and play the instrument, so you won‚Äôt be touching the backrest and in turn get no support from it while playing. Small corner case and totally acceptable to me, but one may have to keep that in mind :-)

I have had one for just over a month now. I agree with every point made. My only gripe is with models.

I wanted/needed the features of the Titan (low sides for the seat, width for the shoulders, lumbard support that can be adjusted) but I have the height for an Omega (172cm). Point is I needed the depth of the seat for the Omega, but all the features of the Titan so I had to make a choice. I decided for the Titan, but the back of my knees now scrape the edge of the seat.

Am I happy to have spent all that money? Kinda: my back has been thanking me to no end since I got the chair, and my knees... well, they can shut up :)
How has it dealt with liquids?

Had mine 3 months now and your right about the firmness i expected it to be softer but because its firm i can use the chair for along time with no back pain.  I sat in the old chair last week and dont know how I put up with it.
I notice you stopped using the head pillow. Any reason why? Also, is the back pillow needed putter is support good enough without it?
comment_reply: Back pillow part, it depends on your height as the Titan has a built-in adjustable lumbar system that may and may not hit the right spot (y-axis), as you can only adjust how much it protrude (x-axis). Since I bought the titan despite being shorter than the recommended height (I  prefer more room space), I'd in my case require a lumbar pillow, and it works well because I can fully flatten the chair out. Please try the chair out before making any purchasing decision, p.s, bought it for 6 months now, still perfectly fine, and been loving it ever since.

comment:
Great review and very in depth, it cleared up a few things and even gave me a second opinion on the exact same questions you covered at least some of them. I also was sucked into the Herman Miller Aeron chair hype, I personally would never spend 900$ for the base version or more to modify it let alone purchase a second hand chair. You can build a decent enough computer your self for around 1k-1500$. I saw a specific website that deals in second hand Herman Miller chairs and when I did a little research I was shocked to see how bad the reviews were for the 3rd party dealer it self "not the chair". There were countless reviews of people getting screwed either by not receiving what they paid for or having a very poor customer service experience and possibly not receiving refunds etc. Anyway I kind of gave up on the Herman Miller brand mainly because of the price point. I used one of these for a few weeks while my work put me up in a Hilton Inn, I will say it was night and day, I'm pretty certain I could've slept in it.
As far as the Secret Labs chairs go I've had almost every chair with pleather, I really hate how hot I get in a full pleather chair and especially the cracking/peeling. I would be curious to see the longevity of the v2 pu leather but my previous experience with pleather chairs this may sway me towards the softweave version. I typically only ever purchase mesh chairs as I stay cooler and the only pleather I have to deal with is the arm/head rests which do tend to peel pretty badly, this current one is around 5-8 years of age and I spent 80$ on it. It was well worth the money and has only given me issues this last year as the main piston/axle broke which makes the chair lean back about 1-2 inches and the bottom is either flat or bowl shaped which makes you want to lean forward. This is killing my back which made me go on this hunt for a new quality chair, I've heard/read many reviews like you saying this one saves and is great for your posture in general.
I was surprised and this brand was even more appealing to me after seeing you can purchase the separate pieces when running into issues, I highly doubt any other brand does that other than those in the premium price point. I would think you'd have to send the entire thing back and get them to fix what ever was wrong but this makes it so much more convenient to fix and like you said the price for the separate pieces are pretty reasonable especially the bottom and back only being 50$.
Pardon any typos/mistakes as I wrote this being dead tired from being up like 36 hrs, I read it over but I was kinda glazing over lol.

I bought this chair hjh OFFICE, 608400, Executive Chair, professional office chair, swivel, PRO-TEC 400 from Amazon in 2017. Cost a little under ¬£400.
Looked good on screen and they said it's good for people upto 2.2m tall. That's over 7' tall and I'm about 6'2". Only problems I have are with the seat base itself.
It's is way too short.  If I sit as far back as I can, about 1/4 to 1/3 of my thigh is not supported.
It cannot not tilt back. Though the backrest does.
Seat base feels like it's tilting forwards too.
And all the instructions are in German. They don't even bother to do an English translation for it.

So the next time I buy a chair, I'm going to go to a shop and buy one where I can test it first.
That's my only real suggestion when buying an office/gaming chair. Sit on one before hand and don't buy over the internet.
Oh! And the chair I bought before the hjh chair was a LANGRIA High Back PU Office Chair. Do not buy this chair. It's bloody awful. Cheap, tacky and really uncomfortable.
EDIT - You're 6'8"...!!?? That's bordering on freakish   :-))...
PU Leather ffs it's Plastic...fake leather but they try to hide it by calling it PU Leather like it's a type of leather.  Have Herman Miller chairs at work, horrible chairs and vastly over priced.

It's not a chair where you first sit in it and it blows your mind in comfort, but when you sit in it for long periods of time like 10+ hours a day every day, your body doesn't hurt at all from sitting down all day. I find myself going back to reviews since I have mixed feelings about this chair to be honest. Referring to this video, it's all awesome as many said before me - straight to the point, well made, professional, honest, etc.. I received my Titan about 2-3 weeks ago, but after I have had an office chair that provided me back support with resistance... That's the only thing I super miss in the Titan... If only they removed that annoying lever and let the back decide on the angle, that would have made this chair really perfect. It compensates with many of its other advantages as you mentioned.

I just bought this chair based on this review and many others. 2020 version in softweave. It's not a good chair. I will say that overall the seat is firm but comfortable but the back is firm and uncomfortable. Also the position of the lumbar support is not good and it actually needs a little of thoracic spine support based on its design. The neck pillow is useless because it you use it as recommended it pushes your spine forward to where you can't feel the back support. I didn't have back pain before getting this chair and after using it for 24 hours have new back pain. I ended up sending it back and eating the shipping cost. Very disappointing and sad that it didn't work out and I am exploring other options currently.
comment_reply: Bummer. Sorry it didn't work out. If you find a chair you like, let me know! Always looking for new chairs to review.

comment:
I have had  the Titan 2020 for going on two weeks now. I've had nothing but upper back and neck strain. I had borrowed a Hermen Miller from work (remote work due to pandemic) and that was a wonderful chair. I cannot sit more then 1 hour on the Titan without having to adjust or get up.

I don't know how much they pay you for these reviews. But YOU know damn well these are shitty chairs, granted it might be the best shitty chair of the racer styles but still a crappy chair.
comment_reply:
@Tech Audit TV I'm angry because I listen to you and countless other youtubers claim this is a great chair. 

The design of a gaming chair (including secretlab) are all the same (with the exception of the titan that has a built in lumbar support which I will get to in a moment).  

1) backrest is a flat board that has wings and headrest area that curve in. couple with a pillow that puts you head and neck in a awkward position if you are sitting straight up.
2) built in lumbar support on backrest. the lumbar pushs out from the bottom of the backrest (your butt area) and forces your back to lean back into the mid and high area of the backrest. Good lumbar support will place that pressure in the middle of the small of the back 
3) you couple point 1) and point 2) and your body is in vary uncomfortable position regardless how you position the chair.
4) if you do not use the lumbar support....because of the curved nature of the top of the backrest you body forces you slowly into a hunch position. (if you head is moved/pushed forward and not aligned with your body the rest of your body will follow.
5) this chair design actually forces you to get your back of the backrest and lean into your desk..which defeats the purpose of ergonomics claimed by this chair.

I have to get up out of the chair within an hour. if I've been sitting on this chair for any amount of time I have to lay on my bed (I have a firm posturepedic bed) or the floor to stretch out. I don't think this is a matter of me getting use to the chair or bad posture on my part. The Herman Miller Aeron I used for 12 hours daily and when i retire at the end of the day I feel no pain I actually feel the same as when I got up in the morning to start my day.

This  chair is no better then any other low grade gaming chair just with better quality foam and PU leather and some pointless feature most people will never use (with the exception of the tilt) on a day to day basis.

a basic Ikea or staples ergo chair feels better then this chair.
I'll borrowed a Herman Miller Aeron when my original chair broke and was waiting on this chair. I will get rid of this chair and invest in a Herman Miller for home use.


the only positive I can give the chairs
1) solid constructions
2) great materials used (cured foam, PU leather
3) looks great

I work from home and game for a total of 12+ hours daily. the main reason for getting this chair was the comfort which is not there.

A comment about what he said at 4:21 about the mattress.  If you think investing $400 in a better chair is worth it, I guarantee you investing money in a quality mattress is worth it.  I spent $2300 on a Sealy Beautyrest Black and by God that is the best money I ever spent.

But back to the chair.  My comment about the SecretLab Titan is that it's pretty good but does not seem to me to quite live up to its hype.  Everyone says its so comfortable and I don't really agree.  It's not UNcomfortable is what I'll say for it.  It's true it does not fatigue your body.  So if you put long hours into working, gaming, whatever at your workstation; you will feel good at the end of it.  Even after 5-6 hours straight I bounce out of it fresh.  That is a good aspect of it.  I would feel achy after that amount of time in my old chair.

But it's not what I'd call "comfy."  You can't relax in it.  I don't get the "wow this is the best chair I've ever sat in" feeling like so many reviewers seem to.  I'm kind of on the bubble of whether it was worth the $400 or not.
comment_reply:
@Tech Audit TV Like you I never spent more than about $100 on an desk chair, so I was expecting quite a lot.  Also I expected a lot because of Secretlab being #1 on a bunch of "best chair" lists and youtube reviews.  Secretlab has done great marketing, I'll give them that.

It seems to be getting slightly more comfortable now that I've broken it in for about 6 weeks.  But I was expecting something more, maybe too much.

comment: Thanks for the great review as a fellow big dude, 6'4/265lbs and just want to finally get a chair that fits.
comment_reply: I have both the autonomous ergochair2 and secretlabs titan. Both are  decent chairs. The titan is too hard  and after an hour of sitting then standing up you can really feel how much loss of leg circulation due to its firmness. Ergo chair  base bottoms out but you can modify the foam for a better one easily.  After modifications on the ergochair I sit on the ergo more than the titan. Also you can‚Äôt return the chairs. I would recommend buying a chair from amazon so if you‚Äôre not satisfied you can return it.  I would return the titan if I could but can‚Äôt. I recently went to staples to test out their 400 chair and I think that chair is better than both the ergo and titan, but not as good as my modified ergo. The best part of buying a chair there is you can return it. Don‚Äôt fall for all the hype that these you tubers  are giving to these chairs, they were most likely sponsored by them. Also, gaming chairs don‚Äôt have the many options of a ergonomic chair. They just have recline and you always have to adjust the recline where with a ergo chair they adjust to you dynamically.  Ergo chairs are better.

comment: If you find this chair uncomfortable with the two pillows attached (between 5'4 and 5'10) it's because your posture sucks from your previous chair. I walk differently, stand differently, sit differently, and am getting tired two hours later than I used to. Use these pillows as guides, they'll save you a boat load of pain. Soft pillows aren't uncomfortable, the hard knotted blocks of muscle in your back are.

comment: Unless you are skinny or a girl, this seat is far too narrow to sit on comfortably! The seat is only about 15‚Äù wide and the wings on the side of the seat are hard and will dig into your thighs if you try to spread your legs even a moderate amount. Everything else about this chair is amazing, but it‚Äôs sad to say that the wings on the seat brings this chair from a 9/10 to a 4/10. I trusted people‚Äôs positive reviews and bought this but I feel like I just got scammed. The only negatives that people mention are stupid things like logos, but no one seems to mention the factors that affect your everyday comfort. The seat itself is actually really soft and comfortable, idk why people are saying it‚Äôs stiff. The design of the seat is unique, but that‚Äôs its downfall because it hasn‚Äôt been proven to be universally liked... Please be careful of small reviewers who receive their items for free. comment_reply: @Emma M√∏rck well i had a cheap office chair before but it's closer to a gaming chair than my kitchen chairs ahahah.  A thing that is important to know: if you never put the chair together, you can return it and they will give full refund. Only need to pay shipping back which i estimated to be roughly 30$CA for me. So i bought Omega and when i got it, i only pulled backrest out of box and asked someone to hold it in my back like if i was sitting in the chair just to make sure how it would feel once i would really sit against it. My idea would have been to ask a full refund if it wasn't feeling right. Backrest was ok so i did the same with seat. We concluded that with lumbar pillow, my knees would reach edge of seat just fine so i decided to keep it and put it together. If omega wouldn't have feeling right, i would have send it back and only lost 30$. And then i would have bought a throne instead. 30$ to test a 500$ chair that will last 10 years was a gamble i was fine to take ahahah

First thing: you're doing an amazing job answering most questions that someone looking for a new chair has in mind so thank you and keep it up and if i decide to buy one, I'll check if i can do it with your link cuz you deserve it really much.
The second thing is more a question. Just like you, I'm fitting exactly between 2 chairs: throne and omega. And I'm afraid to do the wrong choice. Is there a really big difference of width of the backrest between the omega and titan? Or the difference is more on the seat itself (width and depth)? Without the pillow, omega seat depth would be little too long for me but i plan on using the said pillow so it's more about the width of backrest. As you said, arms could not fit perfectly depending on size of the person. Maybe without using it you could be fine? Anyway, the website offers pictures with some measures on them. Try to measure older chair you have and compare with those available on website. comment: How is the PU leather holding up. I'm planning on buying one and ill be cleaning it on regular basis should I be OK?
comment_reply: +Muzammil Khan My chair is still doing great! However, I do see more creases as time passes on the back rest. Do you live in a humid or dry environment? But if dry environment you should be OK if you clean once in a while :) hope that helps buddy!

comment: Have been using my Omega for some time now and I absolutely love it. One thing buyers should beware of is the fact that they will not truly love this chair until it has been broken in. The cold foam will hurt your bottom after a few hours of sitting in it right after you set it up. From personal experience I did not really get full enjoyment from this chair until I had sat in it for about 10-12hrs. That is honestly the only down side, but it's honestly a very big plus because this foam will last you much longer than any other gaming chair out there. The build quality was very impressive down to the screws to hold this chair together. And the lack of noise on tile which I have in my room is perfect! With gaming chairs you definitely get what you pay for and this chair is far better than any DX racer I've owned and they are priced pretty similar with secret lab being a bit more expensive, but the wider back surface area and the less aggressive wings make it feel much better than the formula series DX racers. Secret lab is fairly new to the States, but I'm again very glad I picked this chair. 9.5/10 love it. Just a tiny bit more leg width would've been nice to have.
comment_reply: What do you think of the chair's lumbar support without the pillow? Do you find you need the back pillow to feel comfortable? Also I'm having a hard time finding the chair's upright support. I see a lot of reviews showing how far it reclines, but what about people who sit upright? Can the chair come forward very far to support upright seating?
