comment_reply:
@Crue Steele  @Thor Sine - So the chair was frustratingly sat in the local delivery company's depot so I couldnt even collect from them directly on Saturday, and had to wait until Monday so it is 2 Working Days, not a biggie, just thought i would clarify that for Friday orders.  Its very well packaged, without being wasteful.

After watching a few Youtube videos prior to delivery, it only took about 15 minutes to build and that was in a tight space with my dogs trying to help... so pretty easy.

The parts are really well built and of a very high quality, infact the only thing i would say could be improved on were the little plastic covers that go over the bolts that hold the back of the chair to the base.... they just felt a little cheap compared to the rest... but then the rest of the chair is such high quality, they look fine really.

I've said, I am 5'8" so just at the lower limit of the Titan, but I wanted the inbuild lumbar support.

It is firm but not overly and its very comfy, i can just start to feel the seat 'break in' and give a little more after the 2 - 3 weeks I have had it.
Shoulder wise it keeps me in place and I dont move side to side
Leg wise its just perfect, the edge of the seat right at the joint of my knees
I have noticed my skinny ass has a bit more room to move left or right in the seat (possibly around the lumbar support), but only after sitting crossed legged, so do need to correct my position now and again - however this is very rarely and more my fault :) 
The lumbar support feels spot on and adds that firmness in the right area
Being so short for this I do only have it about 1" above the lowest height setting and the seat tilted back ever so slightly, any higher and i wouldnt be able to touch the floor with my feet flat on the ground.  This does still give you the full 'spring' as you sit down in the chair, and I could raise it a bit more for tip toes or even put my feet on the legs.
Very stable if its laid all the way back, not that I have slept on it... yet.  :) 
I have room to cross my legs and still sit comfortably on there.
Cannot really comment on the armrests as my desk is pretty big so my arms rest on that, but the times i have leant it back to just watch a movie they have been fine.

Overall the build quality is really, really good and I am very happy with the chair!  It might seem expencive but when I thought about it, I spend from 4 to 8 hours a day in it mainly gaming and a little work, so spreading the cost over the years that this will last me, its nothing.  I also went with the fabric finish as I had and know that PU leather does peel after a while, I know SecretLabs use a high quality one, but still.. didnt want to risk it.

Anyway I hope that helps, any specific questions please feel free to ask away.

At first I also looked at a cheaper alternative and narrowed it down to a GT Omega Pro, that seems to have all the same specs (steel frame, cold formed foam, etc) just lacking the internal lumbar support but it was only ¬£200... so that is my second choice... The only worry I have about the Titan since i come in at the short ass range of 5'8"-9" and 'medium build'....  Would it fit me?

(I'd give you a weight but seriously the batteries on the weighing scales have run out... honest.... Reading this now looks like im having a laugh but seriously, you couldnt make this up :D)

So medium build.... a Robert Downey Jr, just slightly more love handles?   Anyway....  

Seriously leaning towards the Titan, I might be on the shorter / lighter end of their scale but now and again i like to cros my legs and take all concideration of my posture out of concideration... which the smaller chairs probably wouldnt allow, I also eat kebabs at my desk and (god forbid) drop some chillie sauce on my chair (so fake leather FTW!).... But;

Do you or the folks here have any experience with this chair who have a similar body size...?

Thankyou again for your review,  good watch!

It is firm with a bit of cushion. I was reading into today about the seat and the material it‚Äôs made of. It‚Äôs on the website. I think it was called cold foam, this is foam that is meant to hold its shape over long periods of time. The seat is not complete cushion. It is like it‚Äôs padded.

comment: i am canadian. This chair is 35% more expensive. On a deal, I can get it for $563, the all black one recently out. I am 6'0 and hella thin (as you can see in my picture) at around 120 lbs. Would you recommend it? Also, how much of a benefit is the high backrest for someone at our height range. Right now I have an office chair which isn't necessarily bad, but I do feel like i'd just like to be "locked in" more. Does this chair give you that?
comment_reply:
After using this chair, I would just recommend anyone try and find a chair that is built for people w/ height of 6 foot and over. The backrest i like a lot! the lumbar support is completely adjustable. I use to work in an office where some of the office chairs backs would only go half way up your back, and my at home chair before this was the same. When i would lean I'd be fine, but those moments when you actually want to just lean back for a moment and fully rest your top back & your head on something, its nice to know it. Has your back lol. 
But if its expensive which I know it can be for people, it was a very "Big" buy for me. I'd say search around, but look for something that does appeal to taller people. This also had me sold because its a gaming chair, so it also fit my streams on Twitch.
Hope this helped! Sorry for the late reply, comment if you have another question :)

But thanks, hopefully I can get a response from you. I enjoyed your video bro! keep it
comment_reply:
HEY LARRY! Thanks for the comment & nice words dude, glad you liked my video :) 
the chair has pretty decent to good lumbar support that it comes with. Idk if you saw my first original video, I went more in depth about what the chair had to offer. And it does come w/ its own lumbar support in it, it has a knob on right side of the chair you can adjust, I have mine all the way supported, just recently I have been thinking about getting a lumbar pillow. I raised my desk up to help my height more which the level of the desk is level w/ the arm wrests. so i cant really tuck my chair all the way in, unless I drop the arms down. So I'm at a cross roads on my streams sometimes with, do I want back support or arm support lol. 
when I choose the back support road I'm perfectly fine and comfortable. Still need to get up here & there to stretch, I tell everyone I sleep then I'm gaming. I'm gaming sometimes for like 8 hours straight to more sometimes. But I'm very happy w/ the chairs current lumbar support. Do note from what I've seen, I know Secret Labs offers lumbar pillows, however, I've noticed they have the Omega lumbar pillow for the normal chairs & also a "smaller" pillow, for their I think V2 Thrown. I dont think they have any pillows to help further w/ the Titan's Lumbar system. Over the weekend I was using a bed pillow for one of my streams. But that was because I didn't lower my arm wrest to position the chair for better back support, so my posture was defiantly leaning in towards the screen.
And really for the cushion support, I do think mine has broken in very well since I use it more, I definitely have a butt "imprint" on my seat, but I still find it good & comfortable. I know my discomforts that I have because, I don't take the breaks i should be taking, I don't go out for walks which i should since i sit so much. If your going to be using the chair for like 4-8 hours, I think you will be very happy with it and love it very much. If your going to use it more than that, you'll still be fine, just know to stretch & take some good size breaks so your body doesn't cramp up like mine :P 
Sorry for the essay letter! hope that answers it for you, any more questions, just write back or you can come by my stream on Twitch, I'm always live on week days
https://www.twitch.tv/cruesteele
Have a good one dude! :)

comment_reply:
She loves the chair. She sits in it for hours of an evening after she gets off work to play the Xbox and watches Netflix....I've tried it out¬†and I would say I find it to be a little more comfortable than my DX Racer (Iron Series) due to the lumber area¬†sticking out more because it¬†arches into my lower spine area¬†somewhat more...
I don't think I'd change¬†the position of the lumber area even it was adjustable because of the backrests¬†outward curve that seems to align with my wife's back and my back¬†pretty well...(If it aint broke don't fix it kinda thing) Don't get me wrong¬†It would have been cool to have an adjustable built in lumbar support¬†but even that doesn't always make the chair any better for sitting in if the chair is well designed to begin with. 
Lumbar support is a nice feature to have but not a necessity with this chair whereas my DXRacer chair¬†would benefit more from having that¬†feature.
The overall style of the Epic Series is sleek and the stitching screams quality. I would¬†definitely recommend this chair despite It's lack of lumbar adjustability....

Hi. A suggestion for the lumbar pillow positioning, if you don't mind potentially affecting a small section of the chair back fabric and back of the lumbar pillow, is to use industrial velcro strips to keep the pillow in place, while still allowing it to be repositionable. Industrial velcro strips vs normal velcro is important or it'll pull off every time you shift position. Placing it vertically near where you'd normally place the pillow on the chair back will allow for some height repositioning. Hope this helps.
comment_reply: @deans6571 Different folks have different body shapes, sizes, and comfort zones. It sounds like the lumbar pillows' resting position suits you, and that's great, though isn't true for everyone. Hence my suggestion which provides a possible solution for many folks with different preferences/comfort zones ^_^

Imma just share my opinion here, don't buy "gaming" or "bucket seat" chairs.
Get actual ergonomic and "24 hour" chairs, unless you really want a bucket/ racing seat for a racing simulator.

My points why I don't like these "gaming" chairs. (Sorry for possibly bad English)
- Most of these chairs come from basically the same manufacturer,  the wheels/base/arm wrests/handles are identical across many different models (look at corsair, dxracer, omega, they're all basically the same)
- The base starts squeaking quite a bit after a bit over 1 year of usage.
- The arm wrests don't have cushions, although are quite adjustible also feel flimsy. When "locked" in place there's still a ton of wiggle. My left arm wrest also ripped at the side after about 1 year of usage, nothing that would bother me or I would feel but still not good quality.
- Although the cushions do remain soft for a long time, I've sat in mine for about 3 years now and never got the feeling like I'm sitting on a piece of wood like ikea chairs after 6 months.
- Cheap and fake leather with poor ventilation. It doesn't personally bother me because I'm used to heat/ not having air conditioning but many people I know suffer from sticky  and wet backs or assess from these seats, especailly during summer.
- Back support is basically non-exsistant, the back is literally a straight line and the shoulders of the chair literally makes it impossible to have your shoulders actually straight down and ergnomic instead of angled forward. Even with the backrest at a 90 degree angle I barely feel the neck pillow and it offers 0 support. The lumbar pillow could help with this but personally I think it's way too firm and thick, making it do more harm than good.
comment_reply: @Tank Vue Cool to hear. I got my omega chair new but heavily discounted so I'm not mad because of the money I spent but for everyone thinking of buying new for the full price I'd recommend going for something else.

comment:
Hey JayRPG, thanks for your video, was usefull and fun. 
I m thinking to buy this chair but I am scared the seat lengh could be too short for me (I am 1m86, 85kg)
Can I ask how tall are you, and with what horizontal seat position are you using the chair?
Another question, when I look at the back, it seems the mesh is a bit loose: in the center area and close to lumbar support. 
is it beacause you used this chair intensively? do you feel the comfort and/or the mesh support has changed since the beginning?
same question for the mesh of the seat.
thanks
comment_reply: @Jay RPG Thank you, I am 189cm 95kg's and have been looking for a "taller" reviewer on this chair!! Nicely done!

comment:
Hey JayRPG, thanks for your video, was usefull and fun. 
I m thinking to buy this chair but I am scared the seat lengh could be too short for me (I am 1m86, 85kg)
Can I ask how tall are you, and with what horizontal seat position are you using the chair?
Another question, when I look at the back, it seems the mesh is a bit loose: in the center area and close to lumbar support. 
is it beacause you used this chair intensively? do you feel the comfort and/or the mesh support has changed since the beginning?
same question for the mesh of the seat.
thanks
comment_reply:
I am 188cm and hover between 95-105kg. I use both horizontal seat positions at various times, sliding it all the way back gets you nice and close to the lumbar support, sliding it forward gives your legs a little more freedom. If I'm typing a lot I'll slide it back.

The mesh at the top is entirely my fault and actually happened when I moved house, things shuffled in the back of the truck and some furniture came into contact with it but it didn't actually change the comfort of the chair in any way since it's right at the top. The lumbar support and middle of the mesh take most of your weight.

If the mesh ended up like that through normal use, it'd definitely be covered under warranty. The seat mesh is still as tight as it's ever been. :)

comment: So,finally,for 8-10 hours per day,which you think is better..this one or the Omega,i mean strictly for comfort? thank's
comment_reply: It would definitely depend on how you sit. If you like to lounge-around a bit/sit back then the Omega is a better choice but if you are more about ergonomics/how you are supposed to sit to prevent long term injury, the Neuechair is the way to go :)

comment_reply:
That's really, specific and odd. Hahahaha. 

What kind of environment are you in? 
That wouldn't be the chairs fault. That's just a product of two fabric surfaces rubbing against eachother. It would happen with any fabric chair. 

Not having it on carpet would probably help if that is the case. Get one of those plastic office mats. I go those since I have carpet and didn't want to get stuck on it. 
I'd be worried about your PC as well man, if it's that easy for static to build up on your chair then I hope for your sake your PC isn't sitting on the ground. The mobo should have standoff pins but better safe then sorry. 

I've personally never had a problem with static electricity.

The vibe seems to be love it or hate it. 

I'm in the former. I love it. I came from a shitty office chair and had shitty posture so I wanted a chair that would support that. I read that it was very firm but didn't see that as terrible given what I came from. It's no couch/sofa but it isn't a dining chair either. 

Right now I'm trying to find some cleaning advice. I vacuum mine often and I don't eat when sitting in it. However dust or sweat stains appear over time like anything. 

But it's still solid, no damage. No complaints from me. 

I have a theory the negative reviews are coming from people who bought a chair that was too big or small for them. A particular theory for 'the chairs lumbar is shit/too big, the sides are splitting, I can feel the structure through the seat' is that those individuals are much larger then they realise. 
Kind of like those obese people on airliners who don't acknowledge how obnoxious they are when their fat rolls are on top of the person next to them and blame the airline for not having larger seats (No offence to those that are self-couscous about it. It's an example of a lack of taking responsibility). That example is extreme and I'm not saying every bad reviewer is obese, just a similar mindset and lack of self awareness.

Likewise, the people who say its too firm came from a couch like chair or they're really light. 

Personally, I'm around 6ft and a pretty lanky guy at around 60-70kg. 

SO there's my review two years on. Still happy with it, not sponsored, just a happy customer.

comment: I have the omega cookies n' cream softweave and it's the best chair I've ever had I love it üòç

Guys... Comeon now...  PU leather is pureed fragments of leather scrap mixed with polyurethane.  PU leather is to leather what dogshit is to potpourri - restated, it isn't. Look, I've got no beef with a gilded lily but lets be honest here.  A premium chair is one that will last a decade, from materials that simply will not break, or deform, over the course of time.  Prime examples of high-end mass produced chairs are Steelcase and Herman Miller; and these chairs can run up to $2000 - for solid ergonomic chairs.  Make no mistake, we're not talking executive, hand crafted leather, one offs - we're talking about high-end chairs intended to do their job well and last forever.  These Titans are - at best - the top of the very bottom. Inflation is a bitch, and just because durable goods have become prohibitively expensive for some doesn't mean that the scale just resets and we're now on poverty time. 

It doesn't mean these chairs don't have a place, simply that these reviews all misrepresent what that place actually is.

Hell, I'm personally looking at one of these chairs for a light duty use in my project room.  I think they're fun, crappy, chairs that will likely last a couple years - tops.  You would do well to think of these products in the same light.  If you can't do that, save up a few more dollars, get something like a Steelcase Leap V.2...  I bought one - with custom foam and fabric - shipped for $1100, just last year.  It's bombproof and will last at least a decade. These simply won't. 

They're not high end, don't be misled into believing they are.

That is the main reason why I'm torn between both colors... Also just so you know, PU leather, or polyurethane leather, is an artificial leather made of thermoplastic polymer used for making furniture or shoes. 100% PU leather is completely artificial and is considered vegan. It's not too "breathable" and tends to crack/flake off. PU leather doesn't absorb water and that's why its easier to clean but it won't ever develop the same luster or patina as real genuine leather. On the other hand, REAL LEATHER (The $799 Napa Leather version) comes from a real animal and is actual hide therefore more breathable and will not crack/flake off; it will definitely last a lifetime and will look/feel better with time.

comment: I just bought this chair and it arrived two days ago. The Quality is outstanding, but the seat cushion is EXTREMELY hard. It's not soft at all. Is that normal? I understand it will likely break in somewhat, but I was truly shocked at how rock solid hard the cushion is, which makes it very uncomfortable. Did that happen with you too, but you like it that way? After reading some positive reviews, I was expecting to be sitting on a soft, cloud-like pillow of a cushion--not the brick like feel it came with. Very surprised here and extremely disappointed.
comment_reply:
As far as the chairs that we've tested goes, and from the feedback of our fellow friends, the cushion is indeed more towards solid, than soft. It does break in a little after time, but it'll not reach the stage of pillowy. 

The best example I can think of is to imagine the front seat of say, a modern BMW or Mercedes.

comment:
Just got one of the SoftWeave omega chairs for 600$ AU  incl shipping. Still waiting for it to come in the mail, but I have no doubt it will be a good chair. My only complaints so far, is the price of the product itself and how Secretlab provides no terms of their promotional offers. For example, during the new years event, Secret lab offered 20% off (or around) and FREE shipping, however this is where it gets confusing. The free shipping is only offered in certain states in Australia, but provides no documentation or reference on what those states ARE. Furthermore Paying 100 dollars for shipping is a bit ridiculous. I don't know what the average price to ship a fairly heavy chair is but it can't be that much surely? 

To move on another point you made in the video, concerning the colors of the chairs themselves, I do fully agree. There just isn't any good options to pick from. Is it really that hard to have popular colors like red, blue green on the omega and titan series? Surely they understand they can make so much money doing this? they're really shooting themselves in the foot here, with all the loss of potential.
comment_reply:
@Shilmar de Pedro For compassion my $100 chair from officeworks is better than the secret lab ones. Honestly 'gaming chairs' are nothing but advertising. They aren't comfortable. I can only conclude that the reason why there are so many reviews saying its good is that they either got the chair for free (like you said) OR they got paid. 
I'm glad I helped you form a rational and wise decision about buying one of these chairs.

comment:
NobleChairs Epic Series is really expensive, and made of real leather. They are even made in such a way that with a little metalwork, you can attach mods to them (In my case, I have a custom made, adjustable aluminum base plate for my Razer Orbweaver chroma, attached via the right arm adjustment mechanism), unfortunately however, it is possibly the least comfortable gaming chair I've ever sat on, even with additional lumbar support, arm pads, and butt-pillow., It's still the stiffest seat on earth, and I genuinely wish I'd spent the ¬£500 on something else. 

Noblechairs are great for build quality, and for modding, but you won't be able to sit on one of these all day without getting a sore/numb bum.

Great review like always iPhonedo. For those considering this chair, I would really recommend finding long term reviews. After owning this chair for only 1 year and 3 months, it has begun to peel and Secretlabs are putting this down to general wear and tear. I would certainly look elsewhere. Just for some context, I have a 100% leather couch (6 years old) and PU leather dining chairs (3 years old) that are in the same environment and have not shown the same sign of ageing. Marketing gimmick because of all these reviews, i ended up buying Titan chair. First day today, it's an okay chair. Not the best out there in market. The  pillow got ripped very easily and is not at all of high quality - actually feels cheap. Installation steps were not that easy but they were not bad either but it could be just me, i usually get chairs pre-installed. I had tried a Herman Miller Embody before this ( which is 3 times price of this chair ), i felt the base of that chair was too hard. This chair is not even close to the quality of a herman miller but it does  feel solid. Remember this is a task chair not executive chair ( make sure you read the difference on internet before getting into it.  Return policy is a total crap on this chair, once you order you are stuck so watch out! 

Update: I informed Support and they promised replacement for pillow and side knobs. But now after a week i see the foam on the base has a dip in it. Its like a hole on the lower side of the chair.
comment_reply: One Year more into the chair. - Still regret this decision. Chair is so hard on the base that it feels like one is sitting on a brick. The frame has held very well but overall this chair is more trouble than actual good.  I have not had any issue with peeling. Trust a real user - steer clear of it, Don't waste your money.

comment: Holy shit! Those Mondo prints are the shit!

I've watched so many of these review videos just to shop for a stupid chair, and this is the first one to make me seriously laugh. Seriously. Well done. Looking at all the main chairs, they all seem to use the same base mechanism and armrest design. The only big difference with this chair is the integrated lumbar support, whereas most others use a sliding pillow. I'd rather have something that locks in place and doesn't need adjusting every time I get up. I like the higher backrest and wider stance, since I'm tall. Still need to see some long-term reviews about the foam durability. Subbed!

This chair is almost as good as my SteelSeries. Which cost twice as much. But this is a lot more comfortable to sit in after prolonged periods. For a gaming chair this really is deceiving.

¬†Because I've had a lot of gaming chairs in the past. Such as DXRacer, AK Racing, & XRocker. 

This may not be as well-known of a company but don't let that fool you. This chair is extremely high-quality. 

There's only one other chair that I've had that comes close to this. Being DXRacer's King series which retail around $700. 

For just around $500. You get probably the best built and certainly the most comfortable gaming chair on the market. 

Only drawback the Omega is that it doesn't have a pass through like other gaming chairs so the lumbar support isn't adjustable. 

But having a full solid backrest actually you don't need it I have found. If lumbar absolutely is important to you. 

You can go for the secretlab elite which is more like an executive CEO version. That chair has built in lumbar. But really for the money you cannot go wrong here. Good Review here!! :b

comment: What are your guys thoughts on the Secretlab Titan? Do you think it‚Äôs worth the $500 price range? Thanks for watching.

I wish people would stop pretending $500 is a lot of money for a chair.  It's not.  Secret Labs are a top of the bottom offering.  They have their place, and I personally bought one for one of my desks - but it is what it is.  Ikea is not classy; it's particle board, paper veneer, and cardboard - whether its all you can afford or not - it's still ikea.

This is a very similar concept.

comment: I got my stark chair last week it's beautiful, but also its the most uncomfortable chair I've ever sat on. It's like siting on the bleachers at a high school game. I'm 5 foot 5 inches, the website says this chair is for my size but clearly it's not. The chair sits so high and the base is so long that when I sit my feet can't touch the ground. After 20 min my entire lower body is numb and my ass. Im so sore from trying to sit and game. If your under 5 foot 7 inches this chair is not for you. They keep telling me to give it 4 to six weeks, I can't even give it 4 to six more mins. Also I wear glasses and the chair has me looking underneath my glasses. This turned out to be a nightmare. Now I have to pay for the shipping and a 15% restocking fee. I'm so depressed right now. I based my purchase of the info giving to me by the website and now I'm screwed. I think this is so unfair. Had I been able to sit on one at a store I would of known immediately that the chair was not for me. You have been warned.... I'm taking the bullet so someone else's doesn't have too. ; (

comment: Hello! I've been trying to decide between a Titan or the Noblechairs Hero or Icon. I'm between 5'9 and 5'10 220lbs. I have back and leg issues. Would definitely need a footrest and I also play guitar. Is this the best chair for me? Being a German company, did you look into the Noblechairs? Does the headrest actually reach and support your neck comfortably? Is the chair hard? How is the built in Lumbar support? Also would you mind linking the footrest you use. Thanks!
comment_reply:
lets start with the footrest i am using:
https://www.thomann.de/intl/mey_chair_systems_efs_93_foot_rest.htm?offid=1&affid=264

i looked into noblechairs but i felt(!) the Secretlabs are more my style. there are some design features i dont get on noblechairs like the metal logo that will stick into your back. i read that on some reviews and overall i decided to go with the secretlab. But keep in mind i got NO experience with an actual Noblechair myself.

all these "gaming"chairs are pretty hard,its more about the constant ability to tilt and change positions smoothly with this chair. but its in fact one of the less harder chairs i ownded so far.
The headrest is a big help,yes. the lumbar support is THE feature that makes me love it. I got no pain anymore...i tend to have a bad sitting posture and now its much better.
Its NOT the best chair for guitar players...you would want a chair where you can get rid of the armrest...titl it back or something. but havent found a really great chair for this so far.
if you follow my channel you will see me playing on this chair constantly now and with the footrest its super!

Since I have an Omega Stealth and watching this video and others like Noblechairs Hero and Boulies Master Series and watching the Assembling of The Omega and Titan and Noblechairs Hero my score for the Comfort of the Omega 10/10, Style 8/10, The Backrest Assembled onto the Seat 3/10, The Five Star Base and Wheels 10/10, Red Stitching 8/10, Stitching on the seat 1/10. As you can see their are two very low scores. The stitching pattern on my seat are not accurate - the one on the left does not match the one on the right. The Backrest on the seat is not accurate and you can even see this on the Titan in this video. 


When I watched an assembling of the Nobles Hero I noticed that the Backrest on the seat was accurate so 10/10. I like the style of the plastic covers and the wheels on the sides of the seats on the Omega and Titan and Boulies Master Series. I dislike the ones on the Noble Hero and every other Sport Chairs that use this old style. 


I just wish that Noble in the future will change the Style like Secretlabs and Boulies. The Angle Adjuster on the Omega is the best style all the others are a poor style.  I don't like the look of the Five Star Base and Wheels on the Noble Hero and the style on the other Noble Chairs are worst.


The stitching and quality of the build looks the best on the Noble Hero therefore I'm very tempted to buy one. The comfort and tilting mechanism and lowering the seat on the Omega 9/10. When I eventually buy a Boulies Master Series and the Noble Hero I'll update this post. One last thing, I just don't like the Arm Rest on the Omega in the 2018 version. They are nice and soft, I just prefer more square style. I have the ones with the branding on the Armrest. I would prefer the ones on the Titan in this video and be soft and leathery.


The Back Cushion for the Omega is the best style compared to all the others and feels great 10/10.

Just received my Titan yesterday. I have to say I'm a little disappointed with the quality of some of the parts. When attaching the back-rest to the base, the position of the brackets was off which made it tough when bolting it up. 

The look and feel of the reclining mechanism/plastic shielding is quite appalling. It doesn't conform well to the chair and the right shielding wobbles about.
 
*The Arm-wrests* could also be much improved. They also wiggle about even when locked into position. The lateral adjustments on them are also very clunky. The material is soft enough, but the front of the wrests should have been tapered down at the front- Or there should be forward/back tilt function for them.

*The seat base* on mine has defects in the foam, where it appears they upholstered straight over hard anomalies on the foams surface.

*The Foam itself* is incredibly dense/hard, though this is not a bad thing for me.
I am almost 6ft at 85kg and find the hard foam provides a very nice resistance and support for butt and legs.

*Seat width* is very accommodating and the side bolsters are very mild (almost flat) and there is no feeling of constriction.  
When I initially sat on it, it felt like a rock, but at the same time extremely comfortable.

*Side bolsters* on back-wrest are quite wide. I have about half an inch clearance on both sides of my hips (34 inch waist)

*Side bolsters* on back-wrest also recede nicely as they work their way up the chair, as to give your arms/elbows room to move. 
 
*The Faux leather* feels nice on bare skin, albeit a little bit slippery.

*The Stitching* seems up-to-scratch. Fit and finish of all upholstered parts is good. 
 
*The integrated Lumbar* mechanism is nothing short of fantastic- Perfectly positioned and provides stiff but plush resistance for the Lumbar region. Adjustment range is also decent.

*The Tilt lock* function isn't great, but it works okay. When locking it at any degree of tilt it makes a clunk sound and sometimes you have to weight the chair to get it to lock.

*The Tilt range* isn't very good either. It only offers around 20% of tilt angle, which is less than other chairs I use.
When locked in a Tilt position there is noticeable play and the chair rocks a little (typical of a lot of chairs with this function.

*Reclining function* works well enough- not something I find myself using terribly often.

*Star base* seems adequate and wheels move very nicely over carpet. 
Rocking motion seems good, plenty of resistance for those who need it- also adjustable.

*Gas lift* works fine. In it's lowest position it should accommodate shorter people as short as 5,9. In it's tallest position it should accommodate people as tall as 6,5. 

*Noise* - The Titan is exceptionally quiet and doesn't make a sound when mounting/dismounting, though The Tilt-lock mechanism does make a clunk when locking into position. (Not offensively loud)

*Velour Pillow* - Extremely plush with a premium feel (I could stroke this thing all day) With a very nice foam density. Offers good support for head/upper-neck. 

*Velour Pillow* - mounting area on Backrest is limited. People shorter than 5,11 will struggle to adjust it low enough for optimal support due to the tapering/flanging of backrest. 

Summary: 
I'm quite happy with the Titan. I feel that Secret Labs would have been better off charging a little more for the chair as to allow a more complete/uniform construction. The Quality just seems a little hit & miss. Overall, I'd say the bang per buck is okay. To my knowledge, the hefty shipping cost also comes out of the chairs price, so that is something to factor in.  

+ It's spacious
+ Comfortable
+ Feels nice
+ Looks nice
+ Very ergonomic in design  
+ Has a good range of functions
+ Relatively quiet operation
+ Excellent Lumbar support
+ Extravagant Velour pillow 

- Some finishing parts are poor quality
- Limited range of Tilt angle
- Arm-wrests could be improved
- Some small defects in foam construction
- Noisy Tilt-lock mechanism
- Geometry of mounting arms Seat to Backrest a little off 
- Upper Backrest design restricts range of motion for Velour pillow


Hope this helps potential buyers make an informed decision. Cheers!
comment_reply: Lmao... You've never owned a Dxracer have you

*The seat base* on mine has defects in the foam, where it appears they upholstered straight over hard anomalies on the foams surface.

*The Foam itself* is incredibly dense/hard, though this is not a bad thing for me.
I am almost 6ft at 85kg and find the hard foam provides a very nice resistance and support for butt and legs.

*Seat width* is very accommodating and the side bolsters are very mild (almost flat) and there is no feeling of constriction.  
When I initially sat on it, it felt like a rock, but at the same time extremely comfortable.

*Side bolsters* on back-wrest are quite wide. I have about half an inch clearance on both sides of my hips (34 inch waist)

*Side bolsters* on back-wrest also recede nicely as they work their way up the chair, as to give your arms/elbows room to move. 
 
*The Faux leather* feels nice on bare skin, albeit a little bit slippery.

*The Stitching* seems up-to-scratch. Fit and finish of all upholstered parts is good. 
 
*The integrated Lumbar* mechanism is nothing short of fantastic- Perfectly positioned and provides stiff but plush resistance for the Lumbar region. Adjustment range is also decent.

*The Tilt lock* function isn't great, but it works okay. When locking it at any degree of tilt it makes a clunk sound and sometimes you have to weight the chair to get it to lock.

*The Tilt range* isn't very good either. It only offers around 20% of tilt angle, which is less than other chairs I use.
When locked in a Tilt position there is noticeable play and the chair rocks a little (typical of a lot of chairs with this function.

*Reclining function* works well enough- not something I find myself using terribly often.

*Star base* seems adequate and wheels move very nicely over carpet. 
Rocking motion seems good, plenty of resistance for those who need it- also adjustable.

*Gas lift* works fine. In it's lowest position it should accommodate shorter people as short as 5,9. In it's tallest position it should accommodate people as tall as 6,5. 

*Noise* - The Titan is exceptionally quiet and doesn't make a sound when mounting/dismounting, though The Tilt-lock mechanism does make a clunk when locking into position. (Not offensively loud)

*Velour Pillow* - Extremely plush with a premium feel (I could stroke this thing all day) With a very nice foam density. Offers good support for head/upper-neck. 

*Velour Pillow* - mounting area on Backrest is limited. People shorter than 5,11 will struggle to adjust it low enough for optimal support due to the tapering/flanging of backrest. 

Summary: 
I'm quite happy with the Titan. I feel that Secret Labs would have been better off charging a little more for the chair as to allow a more complete/uniform construction. The Quality just seems a little hit & miss. Overall, I'd say the bang per buck is okay. To my knowledge, the hefty shipping cost also comes out of the chairs price, so that is something to factor in.  

+ It's spacious
+ Comfortable
+ Feels nice
+ Looks nice
+ Very ergonomic in design  
+ Has a good range of functions
+ Relatively quiet operation
+ Excellent Lumbar support
+ Extravagant Velour pillow 

- Some finishing parts are poor quality
- Limited range of Tilt angle
- Arm-wrests could be improved
- Some small defects in foam construction
- Noisy Tilt-lock mechanism
- Geometry of mounting arms Seat to Backrest a little off 
- Upper Backrest design restricts range of motion for Velour pillow


Hope this helps potential buyers make an informed decision. Cheers!
comment_reply:
Thought I would add a second perspective, not quite as detailed as yours, though hopefully people can see your dissatisfaction isn't isolated. I purchased the Softweave Titan in Charcoal Gray.

Not too sure why they call it 'Soft' weave, the material feels like very new denim, stiff and coarse. Will probably hold up well in terms of durability, certainly isn't what I personally perceive as 'soft.' Combined with the very firm feel of the foam, it results in a 'sturdy and supportive' as opposed to 'soft and comfy'.'

The stitching is disappointing, often wiggling back and forth, with little loose end to be found (even in the middle of the logo on the back.) You'll notice a lot of little descrepencies in terms of symmetry between the two sides.

The armrests wobble a significant amount, the controls are clunky and have been getting stuck. The guide you'll get does nothing to identify which controls do which, so you'll have to figure out the four available controls, from the three available.

Thankfully there are a fair few controls available for the arms, though personally, once I had compensated for the wonky frame, there was little room left for adjustment. These mechanisms all feel clunky and cheap.

I would ask for a return and replacement due to the wonky frame, especially when you're paying high end prices. Though I really don't want to have to try and deal with their customer service again. Mine didn't turn up on the day I was told it would, 3 times, nor was I informed it would not, it was still sat at their premises whilst they had me waste a day waiting for their 'delivery.'

comment:
Just received my Titan yesterday. I have to say I'm a little disappointed with the quality of some of the parts. When attaching the back-rest to the base, the position of the brackets was off which made it tough when bolting it up. 

The look and feel of the reclining mechanism/plastic shielding is quite appalling. It doesn't conform well to the chair and the right shielding wobbles about.
 
*The Arm-wrests* could also be much improved. They also wiggle about even when locked into position. The lateral adjustments on them are also very clunky. The material is soft enough, but the front of the wrests should have been tapered down at the front- Or there should be forward/back tilt function for them.

*The seat base* on mine has defects in the foam, where it appears they upholstered straight over hard anomalies on the foams surface.

*The Foam itself* is incredibly dense/hard, though this is not a bad thing for me.

When locked in a Tilt position there is noticeable play and the chair rocks a little (typical of a lot of chairs with this function.

*Star base* seems adequate and wheels move very nicely over carpet. 
Rocking motion seems good, plenty of resistance for those who need it- also adjustable.

*Gas lift* works fine. In it's lowest position it should accommodate shorter people as short as 5,9. In it's tallest position it should accommodate people as tall as 6,5.

Niceee Review...:) üëçüëçü§ôü§ôüéÆ
Absolutely brilliant video

So I have officially had mine one week  - soft weave Titan carbon black with blue, 2020. I love the chair. I am a 150lb 6ft male. 

BUILD: The build quality is 9/10, very well made and feel extremely sturdy. Every bolt has a lock washer to help prevent it from backing out. Chair casters are extremely smooth and the chair has a nice weight to it when using it. Feels very solid. You feel good about spending $400 on this chair for this reason. The fabric is premium and keeps your body temperature regulated nicely without leaving hot spots or too cool on your back and butt. The chair also looks SEXY. 

COMFORT: This chair has the most adjust-ability out of any computer chair I've ever owned.  With that being said, it gives you a variety of ergonomic seating positions that aid in long computer session. The armrest adjust in all directions,& the seat can be locked in a reclined position in addition to the backrest. The Lumbar support is nice for keeping your back in a healthy posture and the head pillow sticks out enough to be comfortable for resting your head on. 9/10 for comfort. 

CONS: The seat is firm and has very little give. It is a comfortable supportive firm. What does this mean? My car seat in my vehicle is what I would consider the "happy" medium, it is plush and firm at the same time. It is what I was hoping the Secretlabs Titan would be - more on that in a second.The chair's firmness takes some time to get use to, but its more of a perceptive shift if anything. However, I can sit in my Secretlabs Titan without any back, butt, or arm pain for HOURS - like 8 hours plus. I can sit in it all day no problem and feel good getting up. Now - my car seat on the other hand, I can't stand to sit in for more than 4 hours without major back pain which surprised me upon using my Titan the past week now. I would say that although my Titan is much firmer than I anticipated or hoped, it is much more comfortable which I am overall very satisfied with. 

Overall, buy this chair if you are considering. I came from a $120 Homall gaming chair on Amazon, the SecretLabs Titan Softweave chair knocks it out of the park.
comment_reply: venture7o7 perfect with many 8+ hour sitting sessions

comment: I just bought this chair and it arrived two days ago. The Quality is outstanding, but the seat cushion is EXTREMELY hard. It's not soft at all. Is that normal? I understand it will likely break in somewhat, but I was truly shocked at how rock solid hard the cushion is, which makes it very uncomfortable. Did that happen with you too, but you like it that way? After reading some positive reviews, I was expecting to be sitting on a soft, cloud-like pillow of a cushion--not the brick like feel it came with. Very surprised and extremely disappointed.
comment_reply: It's a firm cushion but I never found it uncomfortable, I would definitely reach out to customer service if it's that hard. Manufacturing defects can happen with any product, I'm sure they'll be happy to help.

comment: Couple questions if ya see this and don't mind answering... 1) How's the chair now that it's been 9 months? 2) How tall are you? I ask because I'm 5'5" and they recommend the Omega, but don't like the funky wings on the seat and prefer the seat of the Titan... but worried because of my height that my feet might not touch the floor and that could lead to circulation issues in the legs over extended periods.
comment_reply:
No issues at all with the fabric, foam, or structural integrity of the chair after a year. :)
For number 2, I'm actually pretty tall (6'3") but the Titan has a lot of adjustments, and it can go very low to the ground so I don't *think* you'd have much an issue with it.

comment: This was Awesome , great help in deciding what to get .

Most gaming chairs arent actually any good for posture. If you want a decent chair get one built for long time use, not a bucket seat style chair. The reason those cushions are strapped on is to simulate the natural curvature of your spine, but its isnt actually any good. 
I've spent over 10 years racing cars on track and bucket seats style seats are no good for your back. I had  DX racer chair and got rid of it for decent high end office chair and it was a lot better. 
But obviously, I cant speak for these chairs, but they follow the same style as most "gamer" chairs.

comment:
I am 5'10" and I have a Titan.  There are some things about it that are just too damn big.  The lowest the chair goes is still too high.  I'd be more comfortable going 1" lower.  In that respect, it is hard to understand who at 5'10" this chair really fits well-- someone with longer legs, but a short torso?

The arm rests are also wide as hell in this thing.  At their closest, they dont quite come in far enough for my elbows to naturally hang at my side.  They need to cut the screw holes in the bottom so these arms can be brought in further.

Overall, I think they did a poor job on allowing this chair to be adjusted better for people at the lower end of their spectrum (5'9").  I cant imagine someone 5'9" getting their feet flat on the ground in this char (unless you dont mind wearing boots at your computer).
comment_reply: @Davood Mazraeh Hey, you can read their documentation online for the titan.  It includes precise measurements for the arm rests at their closest setting.

comment: I've noticed a lot of people commenting who are in the middle between these two chairs, high end of the omega and low end of the Titan. I am 5' 11" 140 lbs and I decided to go for the Omega because of the aesthetics. I have been sitting in this chair for the last two weeks normally for 3-4 hours at a time and I have found it very comfortable. In terms of headrest space, there is still ample room above my head (I'd say 2-3 inches depending how you're sitting) so those worried about their head going past the headrest shouldn't worry. In terms of the seat, it has no problem supporting my legs. This chair has a design meant to hug you into the seat, which it does but isn't restrictive, so don't expect to spread your legs apart for than a few inches on both sides.The backrest is not as constrictive though, giving plenty of room to shift around but also keeping you in the chair. Out of the box, the seat is fairly firm but it takes some time to break in the leather and find which position works best for you. If you are looking for a more "fitted" seating experience, go for the Omega, or if you prefer the larger bucket-style seats, then go for the Titan. Hope this was helpful

HEY REVIEW THE NEW SECRETLAB SOFTWEAVE CHAIRS PLEASE
comment_reply:
Not too sure why they call it 'Soft' weave, the material feels like very new denim, stiff and coarse. Will probably hold up well in terms of durability, certainly isn't what I personally perceive as 'soft.' Combined with the very firm feel of the foam, it results in a 'sturdy and supportive' as opposed to 'soft and comfy'.'

The stitching is disappointing, often wiggling back and forth, with little loose end to be found (even in the middle of the logo on the back.) You'll notice a lot of little descrepencies in terms of symmetry between the two sides.

The armrests wobble a significant amount, the controls are clunky and have been getting stuck. The guide you'll get does nothing to identify which controls do which, so you'll have to figure out the four available controls, from the three available.

Thankfully there are a fair few controls available for the arms, though personally, once I had compensated for the wonky frame, there was little room left for adjustment. These mechanisms all feel clunky and cheap.

I would ask for a return and replacement due to the wonky frame, especially when you're paying high end prices. Though I really don't want to have to try and deal with their customer service again. Mine didn't turn up on the day I was told it would, 3 times, nor was I informed it would not, it was still sat at their premises whilst they had me waste a day waiting for their 'delivery.'

Alan Bradley, a games journalist for Rolling Stone, Variety, Gamasutra and Games Radar
Katharine Castle, the hardware editor for Rock Paper Shotgun 
Ben Johnson, the founder of WePC.com

What is your number one tip for first-time builders who don't want to overspend on PC components? 

In the post, I'll be sure to link back to your website, YouTube channel, and social media. Either way, keep up the good work! 

Cheers,
Jacob

comment: here is my problem =/ 5'7 and 220 lbs help please. thanks in advance and btw great video!
comment_reply: I think you could go with either, but the lumbar support on the Titan will likely end up hitting you higher than you'd like. The Omega's maximum weight capacity is 240 lbs., so it will hold you. The Omega's recommended weight capacity is 175lbs., but when I reviewed it I felt like it could easily hold more than that. You could also always go with a Titan, see how the lumbar support works for you, and if it doesn't work out as is, you can buy the lumbar support pillow that comes with the Omega, or use a third-party lumbar support cushion.

comment:
We've strived toward making the Secretlab chair assembly process as easy and efficient as possible, and it should ideally take you under 30 minutes. We've noted on the feedback with regard to the backrest and seatbase alignment and we're actively working on improving this process. Meanwhile, should you be facing issues aligning them, we'd highly recommend you bring a family member or friend to help you if possible:

Person A:
1. Push down and align the right side of the backrest with the corresponding recline arm.

Person B:
1. Insert the M8 fasteners‚Äîtake note not to tighten it all the way; each should go in smoothly if the fastener is inserted straight and correctly.
2. Ensure that the backrest is secured in place. 
3. Repeat the process with the other side and tighten all 4 M8 screws only after all have been inserted.

comment: Do I kick my GF out? She keeps sitting on my Titan cyberpunk edition üôÑ

Just received and assembled my 2020 Titan I ordered a month or so ago.  I didn‚Äôt have any problems assembling, and noticed a few new additions on my chair in comparison to the video.  To me, this illustrates Secretlab is listening and wants to maintain the best gaming chair on the planet.  This also reaffirms my purchase decision.  Anyhow, here are some differences I noticed:  

- Instruction sheet was updated, which was great.
- Allen wrench was included, but also included is a plastic handle and a bit with Phillips on one side and the Allen wrench size on the other.  Just flip that puppy around and only one tool necessary for complete assembly.
-The seat-back bolt covers are now magnetic and snap right in place.  Screws are no longer necessary or included.
-The right side of the seat-back now has a metal guide bracket to help guide into the bracket on the seat bottom.  It slides right in so you can loosely set the bolts while working on the left side.  The left side is a little awkward to line up, but not difficult after a second to learn the movement pattern.

The best part is the end of the video where the guy is just chilling after assembly.  This was me 100.  This chair is awesome!
comment_reply:
Also just received and assembled my 2020 Omega and can confirm these changes have been included for the Omega as well. Took me no more than 30 minutes to full assemble, and that's including taking breaks to admire how gorgeous each part of the chair is. A few things I can add that I noticed about the whole package:

- There are ample warnings not to touch the recliner handle until the backrest is on. Even so, a lock screw is in place so it won't move until removed. Very smart and considerate.
- The most difficult part for me in aligning the backrest was actually not cross-threading the screws. However, getting it aligned was really easy on my own, using my bed to help prop up the backrest.
- The instruction sheet is MASSIVE. There shouldn't be any issues for people with far-sightedness.

I could not be happier with this chair. Next up, Monstertech HOTAS mounts... My poor wallet.

Is there a way to remove the arm rest or install some sort of assembly that would move it out of the way? Would be really useful for playing guitar. Has anyone thought of this or done it?
comment_reply: You can definitely remove the armrests no problem, they're held on with the same screws the rest of the chair is held together with. A swivel option or mod would be pretty cool, but I don't know of anything out there that allows that.

comment: Is there a way to remove the arm rest or install some sort of assembly that would move it out of the way? Would be really useful for playing guitar. Has anyone thought of this or done it?
comment_reply:
Hi there, the armrests are pre-attached to the chair, but you can easily detach them by removing the M8 screws holding them in place. However, we advise against doing so as the armrests play a crucial role in supporting your wrists and elbows, which in turn helps take the strain off your neck and shoulders.

Our full-metal 4D armrests are fully adjustable in four different directions:
1. Up/down
2. Front/back
3. Sideways 
4. Diagonally 

We recommend that you try adjusting them to a position that best suits your preference and needs first. You can also check out their exact dimensions right here: https://secretlab.co/pages/resources We hope this helps!

Can you assembly the chair without the wheels ? I see amazon adapters support replacing the wheels  to have a steady no wheeling chair, thanks

How to use tilt
comment_reply: In case you're still wondering, the left handle under the seat for tilting has two positions, down (locked) and up (unlocked). To tilt you just pull up to unlock, find your angle, and push back down to lock it. I found that if you tilt all the way back and lock, you have to lean back aggressively to get the mechanism to unlock again.

I just assembled my chair yesterday and there are two things not mentioned in this video or on the directions mat that came with my 2020 Titan.


1. The backrest side covers no longer use screws. I looked around my box for a good 5 minutes for them only to then notice it appears they are now attached via magnets. They magnets work great but it would have been nice to have seen that mentioned in the directions.
2. There is a red screw that must be remove before the recline lever can be used which is also not mentioned anywhere in the directions. I fully assembled my chair and actually thought mine was broken when the recline did not want to engage. I got up and look at the side and then saw a little red sticker saying something along the lines of "do NOT remove screw until seat and backrest are attached". Once the screw was removed, it works great. I assumed this was put in place as an additional measure to make sure people did not pull the lever until the seat as assembled since there was at least 3 other warnings not to touch it on the bags.


Besides those two quirks, assembly was pretty uneventful and I was able to finish up in about 25-30 after unboxing.

2 Pillows?! Oh you mean the Backrest pillow, assume you got the Omega version then right? I like that lumbar pillow but from all the reviews I've seen (and I've seen like.. at least 7 different, in depth ones) everyone says that the integrated lumbar pillow is so good in the TITAN and TITAN XL because you don't have this freely moving pillow like the Omega has, what has been your experience with it? Would you have rather had the Lumbar Pillow built in and adjustable? Do you still use the Lumbar pillow? If so, do you find yourself frequently adjusting it or even removing it sometimes altogether? That's another thing one of the reviewers said, was that they just got rid of the lumbar pillow altogether cause it was a bit of a hassle. 

For me I see it this way... I think adjustable integration of it is so much more convenient, cleaner-looking, and just better because you get to decide just how much you want it poking into your back (supporting lol not poking) or how much you don't and you never have to worry about it getting dirty. I don't know how it feels just yet since mine is still not being shipped until another 22 Days from now but... Hoping I made the right decision.

comment: Does the chair just sit on top of the wheel base? Are there no screws to screw it down?
I note that the arm rests don't actually provide any structural support to the chair.  Does that mean they can be removed and it not be a problem?  As a Guitarists, I don't need or want arm rests.

The backrest was certainly tricky but I luckily managed to figure it out and had the entire chair assembled in less than an hour. You really just don't want to tighten the right side M8 screws too much, keep them loose enough that they are within the holes of the chair but still tight enough that they aren't completely falling out on their own, and then the left side of the chair can be lined up with the holes of the other side. You still may have to use a bit of muscle and pressure to push the backrest downwards into the seat to help line it all up. The guy in the video definitely made it look easier to assemble than what it was, though.

Tip for the backrest: The backrest needs to be pushed into the seat for the holes to line up, the best way I found is to put the chair seat facing a wall and then with your pelvis, thrust the backrest into the chair, lean over and screw into the holes.

Thumbs up so others can see üòÇ

Just assembled my chair today. 10/10 comfort and 10/10 assembly with great packaging, nothing was damaged from the shipping. Love this chair.

The backrest installation wasn‚Äôt an issue for me. You guys just need to align correctly. That said, the backrest must be sitting ON the base of chair while aligning. Not on the floor or floating. Took me solid 4 minutes without anyone‚Äôs help for full installation.

Thanks to some of the comments here I didn't find the assembly that difficult. The critical part‚Äîas everyone has said‚Äîis screwing the backrest and not tightening the screws on the right too early. I made that mistake at first, and it looked like I would have really force the left side into alignment. Instead I unscrewed the right side and then aligned the moveable left side, put in some screws on the left, then adjusted the right back into position, and put the screws in there. It took me a total of ten minutes to get the backrest in. However, if I had screwed the right side tight first, I would have probably thrown the chair out the window (if I could have lifted it). 

The video though is a bit misleading it really looks like you screw in the right side screws pretty tight before moving on to the left side.

*Pro-tips for Backrest-into-seatbase installation* :
1. Spray some WD40/lubricant into the screwholes.
After 30 mins of frustratingly failing to align and screw them in, I sprayed WD40 a bit and managed to get all 4 of them secured relatively easier (in less than 10 mins).

2. If you _already_ have a Phillips screwdriver, *cover the screwdriver end of the Allen key with paper/plastic*.
This is to make sure you won't scratch and ruin the upholstery as you are tightening the backrest screws into the brackets.

Step 1: Unpack all the stuff. Step 2: Give no fucks about this fake assembly video. If you are alone, you have the assemble the backrest like this: FIRST allign with the left (moveable!) side and put in 2 screws there (like 3-4 rounds), THEN adjust with the right side. It is over 9000 times easier than starting with the right site. If you start with the right site first, you will sweat a lot and waste so much time of your life and start to hate the chair and this is no good, since the chair is really good!!

The headrest comments gave made me some good ole' laughs; thank you.  I did the install myself.  What I did is attached the right side bracket first, per the instructions, and then rotated the left side metal bracket in place and pressed the backrest downward (have to muscle it a bit) to align the holes and installed the top screw first and then the bottom screw. If you noticed in the video how he had his arm atop the back rest (@1:47), you would do the same but have to muscle the backrest downward with screw in hand and ready to go. Once you get one screw in the second screw installs easier.

My boyfriends chair just came in the mail today while I was home. I decided i'd put it together while he was at work. It took me 30 minutes to put it together by myself. Most of the time was unwrapping it and reviewing this video section by section. I didnt bother with the paper instructions because I do better with visual examples. I love putting things together plus can change my own tires so I know very well you dont tighten one bolt and move on to the next. Get the screws in by hand but dont tighten them. Once all are in place and feel like its set properly without force then tighten but make sure to switch by going across from each one like an X formation. You may not have to do an X but my father always told be its just best to do it that way so I always do. So when I got to the point of tightening I did the bottom right side of the back of the chair then changes to the top left on the other side and so on. Take your time and be patient. I know my boyfriend has no patients and get anxious so I felt I'd be kind and save him the stress. Im tempted to buy one for myself now after sitting in the finished product. Its super comfortable

comment: Cant get the side covers in the screw hole
Completed!!!

For those having difficulty aligning the backrest with the screw holes, be sure to attach the right hand side of the chair first (the side with the adjustment lever). Also, leave the two screws on that side a little extra-loose, to give you more movement while aligning the left side. The left side bracket is free-moving, so it's a matter of moving BOTH the seat back AND the bracket until they align. Yes, it's a little awkward, but if you still have trouble, try having someone help support the seat back while you align the holes. I had very little trouble getting the backrest attached, so I hope this helps. 



Also, for those asking about how to incrementally lock the "rocking" function of the chair, you can't. And that's by design. You don't lock it, you adjust the tension of the rocking feature by way of the rotating knob on the bottom of the chair, until it feels right. That feature is either the "locked" position (upright) or the "unlocked" position (where you can rock back according to the tension you've set via the knob). Just play around with the tension on the rocking mechanism, along with the reclining positions of the backrest to achieve your desired seat orientation.
comment_reply: @helix19667 Great to hear, and glad to be of help!

@Charmz Sorry, I'm not actually much of a youtube commenter. That said, I'm not sure if it was the chair or my previous posture but there was a pretty painful week long acclimation period. Now that I'm used to the chair however, I would not go back. The softweave is pretty cat resistant. I do have an extra pillow on top for longer gaming sessions (which may have contributed to some of the acclimation discomfort), because I'm not one that has much for "natural" cushioning. The appearance has grown on me, but I'd still have preferred a more simple black appearance. I also ordered one for my father and he certainly appreciates the lumbar support. 
The reclining feature is pretty bitchin. Unlike my old chair which did not recline, I can fall asleep in this bad boy and not suffer a sore neck the following day. Because it's the winter, I can't really comment on the breathability vs a leather or pleather seat, however, logically I'm sure there will be a benefit in the summer months. Not sure what else I can say. Cheers.

comment: <-- Ordered a titan. with the soft weave option. I'm curious as to how lighter white stains might show on the fabric. Will post back once I've experience with this chair. For science. :D TBH. I was torn between the Omega and the Titan. I wanted the omega for the other color option on the softweave, as I'm not too fond of the cookies n cream's appearance, but I decided to go with the titan because, rather than giving you a lumbar pillow, they have a built in adjustable lumber support which is a higher end feature in office chairs and what not.  Some cars and lazyboy chairs even have adjustable lumber support. I'm not quite rich enough for the Nappa Leather model, and didn't want PuLeather as it doesnt have the best longevity and more importantly, breathability, which the soft weave should solve.  We'll see if I made the right choice. PS: sorry, I didn't find your affiliate link until after I purchased the chair.

You can read more about why firmer seats are better for your back and you: https://blog.secretlab.co/stories/is-a-hard-or-soft-chair-better.

comment:
First of all if you would like to support my channel and order a Secretlabs Chair you can get it from https://bit.ly/2QFJ2YL


I wanted to update you all on some things with this chair.  Great chair BUT things have taken a slight down turn and while it is nothing I am totally in up in arms about I‚Äôm going to post them so you know what I have seen and experienced.  


I released a second video on this https://youtu.be/THR7LdF4CpM

My 2020 Titan has developed a few issues so far.¬†

The first is it started to squeak badly on lean back, man it was terrible and driving me nuts I contacted Secret Lab and they sent a really helpful sheet showing where to add a little penetrating lubricant and it resolved it and chair is silent again.  

However this is not it all sorted, it seems to have also developed a strange wobble as I lean back, it‚Äôs like there is a slight bump in the leaning mech, however I don‚Äôt think it is there and have worked out I think it‚Äôs the piston shaft  moving as my weight shifts as I lean back and you can feel it through the base pad.  

I contacted Secret Lab on this as well and they sent a response about the piston not being aligned and is normal and nothing to be concerned with. Tbh I‚Äôm not 100% happy with either that answer or the actual issue, for a premium chair I would expect the lean to be silky smooth.   

Im still talking to them at this stage.¬†

Edit September 2019 Update.¬†

Further to the above the wobble remained, I have 100% narrowed it down too the piston shaft wobbling as the weight changed as I lean back, this is at its worst when the chair is fully extended, its clear to see when you lean and the piston rocks.¬†

Sadly a 3rd issues have arisen in that the foam on the front of the seat base appears to have come loose and dropped, its seems there is a front patch of foam along the front thats glued on and this glue has come loose on the RH side. I have a very noticeable bump now as the foam drops, I can man handle it into place but it just moved again as soon as I sit on it.¬†

Secretlabs have sent me a replacement seat pad and piston ans so far my issues have been resolved. .
comment_reply: Mad's Tech Reviews & Tutorials with so many issues why on earth would you spend another ¬£379 on one?

comment_reply:
Dave Innit Hi Dave.  

They replaced my seat pad for the loose foam, my piston and the base tilt mech a few weeks ago. 

Interestingly the new base tilt mech started to squeak in just a few days after fitting just like the first one but some lube delt with that.  

So that‚Äôs 2 with the same issues !!!  

The old piston was just totally knackered it was shocking once it removed it. Still don‚Äôt know how it got this bad so quickly and the new one has resolved my issue with the movement, the question is for how long right now.

I LOVE the chair but to be honest at this price the issues are disappointing.   I‚Äôm going to do a video on this at some point soon and they may not like it but my current thoughts are that the chairs are very well designed but a little fragile.  Perhaps the high price tag is to offset the cost of repairs.  

Would I buy another one ? 

Absolutely yes, I want the dark night edition soo badly.

Got my debit card in my lap, getting ready to pull the trigger on the Omega! Just watching a few more reviews to reassure myself. I have chronic thoracic back pain, and finding a chair that doesn't exacerbate it, has be... well... a pain. I think this one might be the one!
comment_reply: @Dr. Savage of course!! i hope you finda chair you love!

comment: Got my debit card in my lap, getting ready to pull the trigger on the Omega! Just watching a few more reviews to reassure myself. I have chronic thoracic back pain, and finding a chair that doesn't exacerbate it, has be... well... a pain. I think this one might be the one!
comment_reply:
@Dr. Savage Happy to help. Also, if you visit the Vertagear website, you can chat live with an employee and ask them any questions you have. They have incredible customer service. When I got my chair, it had a faulty raise/lower mechanism, which was just one part. The chair was functional, but I couldn't lean back in it. They sent me and ENTIRE new bottom chassis, wheels, 5 star base, compression arm and everything. I now have loads of backup parts! 
Also, if you do go with the Vertagear chair, upgrade to the 4D armrests, it's TOTALLY worth it, also, the bigger wheels don't make much of a difference, but are worth the extra money just to have a set of backups. I love my SL2000, and as someone who live with pain every day, it's the most comfortable chair I've ever owned. It's also most certainly the most comfortable computer chair I've ever sat in.

comment: Got my debit card in my lap, getting ready to pull the trigger on the Omega! Just watching a few more reviews to reassure myself. I have chronic thoracic back pain, and finding a chair that doesn't exacerbate it, has be... well... a pain. I think this one might be the one!
comment_reply: @Dr. Savage The prices are relatively the same, but I read horror stories about how uncomfortable the Omega is, and everything I'd read about the Vertagear SL2000 was great concerning comfort. As I said, my spine is pretty well ruined. I have arthritis, and cyst in my cervical spinal cord, kyphosis and degenerative disc disease, and I can sit in the Vertagear chair with minimal discomfort for around 3 to 4 hours. In my old chair, it was about 45 minutes. My old chair being a mesh back office chair. I feel like I definitely got what I paid for with the Vertagear SL2000. I would buy another one.

comment: Got my debit card in my lap, getting ready to pull the trigger on the Omega! Just watching a few more reviews to reassure myself. I have chronic thoracic back pain, and finding a chair that doesn't exacerbate it, has be... well... a pain. I think this one might be the one!
comment_reply: @Dr. Savage After further research, I decided NOT to go with the Omega, and instead went with a Vertagear sl2000. Much better chair.

If y'all want 100% honesty here it is.

I used my friends secretlabs chair I don't remember the model but it I was within the chairs limits so I wasn't missing it or whatever. At first yeah it was kinda comfortable, 6 hours in and I tried to stand up only to realize that I couldn't during to the pain in my tailbone, YES it hurt that bad. It was bad enough that I had to have my friend force me out of the chair because I couldn't do it on my own. The damn thing caused that much physical pain. I've never experienced that, even with a $60 chair from Walmart! That being said I also can't stand the fact that the arm rests look like some cheap shit you'd get from Walmart too, and feel the same way. In my opinion it doesn't get a rating, way too damn expensive of a chair to be causing any sort of discomfort. FYI you can get a normal office chair typically for less and it'll be more comfortable and still well built. Fun fact: throw "gaming" in front of anything and you can automatically add $200+ tot he price tag. All gaming chairs are nothing but gimmicks!

comment: I can‚Äôt decide between this and the vertagear sl4000
I‚Äôm 5ft 11 and 160lbs, most of my height is leg so would the omega be better for me than the titan?
comment_reply:
You can go either way you want. It really boils down to:

If you want a wider seat base go with the Titan. If you want the narrower bucket style seat go with the Omega. 

The only other thing that might make up your mind is the different color schemes/styles. I think there's 1-2 different options between them. So if you want one of the different options, I think both will suit you well enough to where you can choose the one that had the style/design you prefer.

comment: Why can't they make roomy gaming chairs for people around 5 foot 7? I don't wanna buy the Titan because it isn't recommended for my height.
comment_reply: Yeah, that's kind of how most of these racing style chairs are. The Omega's sides are somewhat pronounced (I also reviewed the DXRacer F-Series its sides were the same way.) I do tend to sit with my legs spread wide---which I guess isn't the right way to sit---but when I was reviewing the Omega and DXRacer F-Series the raised sides made it uncomfortable to sit with my legs in a wider position (because they would rest on the raised sides.) The Titan does have slightly raised sides but they aren't nearly as pronounced as the Omega & F-Series and I think there are a few other racing-style chairs out there that offer something similar. If that's a deal-breaker, though, your best bet would be an office chair---as they won't have the bucket-style raised sides.

comment_reply:
@xLegend 89 I actually bought the softweave version of this chair anyway. It is sturdy, the armrests are premium quiality as well as the softweave, the bottum and the tilt function. The softweave actually feel a lot less rough than I would have imagined and the chair looks really good. 
But this is by no means an armchair. The build is definitely better than cheaper chairs but you don't just dump into the chair. it is not soft. It is a rough build with coating, if that makes any sense. The backpillow if what provides you with comfort and relaxation. My stomach is in a better position in this chair though. Sometimes I could have wished that the sitting piece was further out to offer more support to my legs (eventhough I'm 173 cms) but tilting the chair just a tiny bit seems to offer the support I need. I don't think there's no such thing as the perfect chair and all chais takes some getting used to. And none of the other gaming chairs have a more armchair like build, so maybe that critique is unjust. Then you could by a proper work "boss" chair but that won't probably have the tilting functionality and risk getting too soft for your posture in the long run maybe? Anyway those kinds of chairs are many times more expensive.

comment: I‚Äôm 5‚Äô9‚Äù and about 177 lbs and I don‚Äôt know which of the chairs fit better for me! After saw this video I guess would be the omega but I cant decide yet!
comment_reply:
You're the same size as me and so I think either would work for you. If you want a roomier chair, go with the Titan. If you want a chair that fits you a bit more snug, go with the Omega.

Also, note that the lumbar support on the Omega and Titan are different. The Omega comes with a pillow---which is pretty good in terms of lumbar support pillows---and the Titan comes with built-in adjustable lumbar support. I really like the Titan's built-in lumbar support because I can dial it back a bit.

Ultimately, both chairs are good options and I think either would work for you. It will just come down to how you want the chair to fit and what lumbar support style you'd prefer.

comment: Since you have reviewed both the Omega and Titan, which one did you find more comfortable and a better fit for you?  I'm the same size as you are and am trying to decide between the two chairs?
comment_reply: Thanks for the prompt response, appreciate it.  Keep up the great work.

comment: Since you have reviewed both the Omega and Titan, which one did you find more comfortable and a better fit for you?  I'm the same size as you are and am trying to decide between the two chairs?
comment_reply: They're both really similar in terms of comfort and how they feel, but I prefer the Titan and its built-in lumbar support over the Omega's lumbar pillow. The Titan is also roomier, which I like, but if you want a tighter fit, the Omega would be better.

comment: I'm 5'7 and about 200 lbs, would the titan be entirely too big for me? I really like the lumbar adjustment on the titan.
comment_reply:
I think the only issue you might run into is where the adjustable lumbar support lines up with your back. I'm about 5'9" and the one thing I initially noticed was that the lumbar support hit me slightly higher on my back than I would have liked. So, that might be an issue for you. Although, I have been sitting in the Titan for a few months now, and now that I'm not trying to think about every aspect of sitting in it (for the review), I don't notice the lumbar support placement as much anymore.

My gut says that it would probably be more than fine for you, but it really depends on how important the placement of the lumbar support is to you. I know you can purchase the same lumbar pillow that comes on the Omega separately as well. So, worst case scenario, you could always add their pillow (or a third party option) later. Obviously, not an ideal way to approach it, but if you did go with the Titan and you didn't like where the lumbar support hit you (but you liked the rest of the chair), that would be one way to fix it.
