comment: I'm 200cm and 79kg, should I get the XL or the regular?
comment_reply: I have a video on my channel comparing the two, which might be worth a look, but... id go for the Titan if i were you. i've not had any problems with the length of it (obviously you've a little bit on me in terms of height), but i think the width of the XL would be too much. So if you had to make a concession somewhere, id say go for the slightly shorter model, but have it fit you well on the back and seat, rather than the marginally longer one, but have it be too "loose"

comment_reply:

The arm rests are quite wide (the actual pillar for them) so while the top is adjustable it sounds like it would be the pillar that would be on your legs. But, I don't think that would be an issue. The gap between the pillars is 25in (64cm), and on the Titan XL is 27in (69cm)
Hope that helps!

comment: I just bought the 2020 titan today because my back hurt with my random chair. Hoping its noticeably better than a similar dimension old no name chair.
comment_reply: It is way better than my old only height adjustable one. I'm 510, and I think I might prefer the omega, just to have the option to lower slightly if I want. As it is, the titan works well enough for me, but I have it lowered all the way. I find the padding soft but supportive. It's a good chair, and very nice looking, but I do wonder if I should have just spent 100-150 at staples. I still get some pain sometimes, but it's way better. My table is slightly lower than it should be, and monitor isnt placed right; so if I fix that I might be able to improve things further. Overall, I love the chair, but have no idea if it's worth it unless the aesthetic is important.

comment_reply:
Interesting! I just got the Omega to review and have been sitting in it for the past week. To me it feels very similar to the Titan (which I love). So, the Titan might not be for you, then. Probably the same level of firmness between the two.

Yep, those look pretty similar. The base is different and the side plates look different as well.


But, I think that happens a lot on these racing-style chairs and I've been holding off on mentioning it until I get through more reviews. In reality, there are likely only a handful of chair manufacturers (all probably in China) and the companies that sell these chairs go through those manufacturers.

And, then the original manufacturer probably has customization options so that these companies can sell their own version of the chair (different color schemes, cover material, cushion material, arm rests, lumbar options, bases, casters, etc.)

It will be interesting to see how many of these chairs are actually the same. I know people have told me before that they've gotten a knock-off DXRacer, but I'm wondering if some of these cheaper chairs that look like the big brands aren't, in fact, the same exact chair, just being sold by a lesser-known brand.

And, yep! I don't watch Twitch a lot, but when I do, Doc is who I watch the most. He's the best.

comment_reply:
i have been using the titan for over a year, the arm rests are comfortable, they have over the year become slightly indented from where i put pressure on them with my elbows, which in theory effects the aesthetics a little bit, but it is still really comfortable. 

you do have to assemble the chair yourself, my arm rests don't wobble but it's possible some people don't do as good a job putting it together. 

over all i give this chair a 5/5 especially given the price point and that i find it more comfortable than numerous chairs that cost over 2 grand.

comment: Not a bad review, no one ever mentions how the arm rests are though, are they comfortable?  too soft? too hard?  I hear the armrests wobble a bit on the SL chairs?
comment_reply:
Thanks for the heads up on arm rest comfort. Definitely something I will start paying more attention to in future chair reviews.

The Titan's arm rests are comfortable I'd say. I can't say that there's anything special about their comfort level, though, as I think most of these style chairs arm rests are made out of the same material. But, they're wider than most other arm rests I've seen. And a lot of chairs' arm rests have a sort of groove in the middle of them, which might not be great for everyone, as the groove might not properly fit everyone's arms. The Titan's arm rests have a flatter surface (with a very slight groove).

The arm rests do wobble a bit. Not at the base/support of the arm rest, though, but at the arm rests themselves. And, that I think is due to how many different directions the arm rest can be adjusted (side-to-side, forwards & backwards, and angled).

The slight wobble isn't something that really bothers me, but I might not use the arm rests as much as you or others do.

comment_reply: @Gestaffel Stein finally got it today. First impression is, it's amazing. Very heavy but in a good way, because it feels very firm. Titan seems like a premium product. I was reading somewhere the wheels are plastic but i don't think they are, or at least, not any more. It feels like stiff rubber to me. oh and the seat is not hard at all, perfect under the butt from day one. So i'm very pleased with my purchase, despite the shipping issues. The only thing now is to see how the leather holds up but that is hard to predict at this point. Other than that i sincerely recommend it.

comment: How is the chair now since you got it? Any pros and cons?

comment: Crue, firstly thanks very much for making this video... very helpful. Do you find that there is enough support under your legs? For example, is the seat deep enough? I notice that at 54cm, it is not as long as a few of the competitors. At 6ft 5 with long legs, that's my main reservation on this chair. Also, how are you finding the lumbar support? Is it effective enough? It's coming up to a year since you got the chair. How is it bearing up to the wear and tear? Are you still totally happy with the purchase?
comment_reply:
Bella Cavachon 
Hey! Glad you liked it! 
I think I know what your asking about the legs, I would say it probably could use a bit more support under the legs when I think about then couple of times I‚Äôve done 24 your streams (2 or 3) 
I just finished a 7 hour stream and still completely comfortable! 
1 year later, no real wear & tear. I do recall one incident where a screw fell out under the chair, idk from over time if unscrewed itself or if I didn‚Äôt screw it tight enough. But it went back in fine. That was like 2 months ago really. 
I still think it‚Äôs great & love it, I work a desk job & between the full time job & my streams I‚Äôm always sitting down. I much prefer the Titan over my chairs at work. 
The seat itself is not too much cushion, it‚Äôs more of a good firm foam so it feels like your sitting in an actual desk chair & not a couch cushion chair.

The lumbar support, probably could be a bit better. It‚Äôs there, it works. This is my first real chair with lumbar support, you can feel the difference when it‚Äôs full rolled on & off. 
I haven‚Äôt experienced any lower back pain. Only discomfort I ever recall with the chair, which might be me, sometimes my elbows hurt on the arm rest after long periods of time, but I think for some reason it might be me pushing my elbow into the chair because of my gaming, I play FSP & survival horror with friends, so I can be very into a game. 
The arm rest aren‚Äôt really padded, but they are not uncomfortable. Like I said. Only after long hours I‚Äôve noticed that I start to get pain. 
And I‚Äôve felt sore after my 24 hour streams but who probably wouldn‚Äôt? 
The chair I think for what I paid ($350 I think, around their) totally worth the price in my opinion. 

Once again! Thank you watching & commenting. Still plan on doing a follow up video sometime May!

comment: Hey I have a few questions. I just received my Titan, and as much as I love it, I have noticed a few oddities. When I slowly rock the chair seems to ever so slightly drop just a tiny bit, and then raise when going back to the regular position. Or at least this is what I think is happening. Also Is the piston only supposed to use 2 of the 3 section of the cover thing? The middle part never extends fully.
comment_reply:
Our engineering team has read the description of your issue and they have investigated and understood the slight bump which you are referring to. They have informed that this slight bump that you are experiencing is actually the movement shift between the hydraulics piston and the tilt mechanism. 

At the connecting joint when the hydraulics piston is inserted into the tilt mechanism, there is a small room of free play at the connecting joints and this is by design to prevent any excessive tension on the tilt mechanism through usage over time. However please be assured this is very normal across our chair and will not compromise the safety and quality of our chairs! :)

We hope the above helps explains and clears up any concern you may have. As usual please do not hesitate to contact us if you have any queries in future thank you :)

However, I can't say what the quality is like now as they improved their chairs. The current Omega has a different shape but mostly the same materials retained. But assuming the PU is the same, treat it with care, and in a controlled environment, you shouldn't see any peeling for at least 2 or 3 years.

comment: Liam, how has been your experience with the chair? How tall are you and how well is it fitting your body?
comment_reply: It's been great really. For the past year, the chair is still very sturdy. A little compression on the seat cushion, but that's to be expected. The compression isn't that exaggerated as well, it is probably a squashed by less than a CM from the original size. No rips or tearing of the leather around the back rest area, but I've noticed a small leather tear near the seat area, somewhere in between the thigh rest area. Probably due to compression thus it kind of wear off. But I don't see it on anywhere else, could be my own mistake of accidentally scratching the leather. I'm 168cm and the chair is big enough to fit me inside with some extra space.

comment: i think the freely recline is because you mounted it wrong, if you look at the timelapse, you made it so that it reclines forward not back,

I can recline with my feet up on my Titan XL without a problem, and I'm 6'4". Watching the assembly portion of your video, it looks as though you attached the base wrong way around. The pivot pin should be nearer the front of the chair. I think you installed it with the pivot pin to the rear. That would position the shaft support more to the front and perhaps cause balance issues. Consult the assembly manual online.

comment: Hi, I just received my chair & put it together today (2018 version was on sale). During your unboxing, I noticed when you put the tilt mechanism on the bottom of the chair it looks like it is around the wrong way.  The top of the triangle should face the back of the chair & the white sticker should be facing towards the bottom, not the top. This could explain why you can't find the tilt lever easily. :)

I've just recieved a Titan and on day 2 now at the end of a 12hr shift my legs are killing me. My previously chair was fine but it's over 10 years old an needs replacing but the base and overall synchro tilt is far more comfortable, unfortunately can't get them anymore. From all the reviews I've seen people say they get used to it, but seeing it in person I think that's less likely. For chair ergonomics, if you google it, the chair base should be flat and pressure shouldn't be on the legs behind the knees. Designing an office chair around a car seat is silly as they perform different functions and for your body to be in a similar position to when you drive you would be practically sitting on the floor. The back support is amazing however, pretty surprising to be honest. There's some plastic parts like the wheels but they function surprisingly well. It did come with 2 defects one being a very rusty bolt and the other the arm latch fell off that will need replacing. I can tell they've put a lot of thought and effort into the chair but there's too many positive reviews, it feels artificial. Is it really that good? Is harder better? Will I really get used to it? Do they know something the internet doesn't know about ergonomics or is the native tilt in the seat not that bad after a bit? I'm trying to work out wether to return or not because there's very few quality chairs anymore. There is the ergo miller logitech chair but that's many times more expensive and is it even better, sounds like more hype than substance.
3 year review anytime soon?
comment_reply: @Crue Steele I'm guessing sth got in the way. Still planned?

comment: Thanks for the super honest review. :)

I sit in mine crosslegged. Don't ask me why. I've been doing that since I was a kid and neither my dad, nor any teacher (back way back when) has ever whipped me out of the habit. For when I do sit like a normal person I use a memory foam foot rest. Crue is spot on about the monitor and desk being as important as the chair itself. 

I cannot recommend enough having a monitor arm over a monitor stand. The flexibility it offers you solves most issues that a fixed monitor presents.
Desks are often more of a challenge and adjustable desks can set you back. This is why i suggest a decent foot rest, especially the ones you can turn upside down and use as feet rockers. 

This last year has taught me that for every dollar (pound, yen, whatever) you spend on your PC, you should think about setting aside at least another half dollar for your body - i.e. The desk, the monitor, foot rest, wrist rests or pads. The most important part of your setup should always be YOU. An extra 5% of FPS won't help with back pain, or knee pain. Spending some of that budget on yourself will go a long way to maintaining the most valuable thing you have, your health and the overall experience will be so much nicer. Good luck, peace out and happy sitting. :)
comment_reply: Amazing comment dude! And 100% agree w/ everything you said :)

comment:
hey man, not sure if you are still following up with comments here but great video! thanks for the in-depth review. 
I've been looking for a decent chair since i spend hours on my pc coding + gaming and might finally pull the trigger on secretlab. 
Just wanted to ask, since i fall in the range of both Titan & Omega, is having an integrated lumbar support worth the extra $?
comment_reply:
@Mujibul Islam Dipto my pleasure :D
lmao, i do get asked that a lot, and it doesnt feel like concrete. 
If you go to their site and look under Omega/Titan, they tell you the material its made of. 
Its very firm, but not in an uncomfortable way. I have heard some people say it is to firm for their taste. 
But typically for chair you want it to be more firm than cushion. 
Chairs that have a lot of cushion flatten over time, lose their shape, and some cases you end up sitting on the metal plate at the end

comment: I finally pulled the trigger after a couple of years of wanting one, figured I'd share here too.  The seat is definitely stiff, and it can give you some iron booty, but the build quality absolutely gives that premium feel to it.  The back is comfortable, and all the positions you can put it in is awesome.  I've only had it for about a week or two at this point and the seat is pretty stiff.  It still feels hard to sit down on it, as there's definitely no squish to it, but over-all it's a much more comfortable sitting position.  I kinda miss my gel office seat on the ass, but the posture and the multiple positions you can throw it in is so much better on the back.

Thanks so much for these reviews. It's so nice seeing a "human" review on the chair that isn't highly produced fluffy crap that says little to nothing about it. I used your affiliate link from the first year video to purchase a Titan Charcoal Blue 2020. I'll definitely check out Birb's channel as well!
comment_reply:
I'm glad you enjoyed! Thank you for the kind comment :D 
Let me know what you think of it when it comes in! That Charcoal Blue is really awesome looking! Right shade of dark and a good color of blue! :D

comment: Hey man, been investigating 'gaming' chairs and 'ergonomic' chairs over the past weeks. The SecretLab Titan 2020 has been grabbing my attention for a long time due to it being sponsored with the ongoing CSGO major. I have been on the fence of ordering a softfabric charcoal-blue chair but I am currently stuck with a few questions.I'm 6'5", I have big ass thighs (kickboxer-level big) and I was wondering whether the seat is wide enough for someone with big thighs. Ergonomic chairs look really damn nice as well but the cost and the overall lack of headrests can't justify them.. Back to the Titan, I am also kinda scared for the warranty and the return period. You apparently can't return a chair once assembled. Looking forward to a reply :)
comment_reply:
I hear you dude! If you check out the Titans specifics, it says the width of the seat base is 22 inches. Honestly If I was your, i'd sit down and measure real quick how wide you would be. If your 22 or less, id say go for it. and when it comes in, before assembling, just take the chair out, put it on a couch or the floor, sit on it real quick to see how you measure up. 
My chair, the arm wrests when i extend them all the way out, they go to the edge of the seat. So if your 22 or under that, and if it comes in and you test it, and your sitting okay in it. Go ahead & fully assemble it, cuz for mine, your arm wrests should not be in the way of you when you go to sit.
In the pics too you can also see how the armrests are for the 2020, they shouldnt be blocking you if you go to sit in it.

If you do end up getting it, let me know how you make out dude!

comment: Anyone else notice they took that stupid 2020 off the chair? Lol probably realized it isn't a good branding after 2020 being such a shit year.

Fuc* now i'm buy this Hype

Song Name was interesting me
Very beautiful but 409‚Ç¨ ....

I facebook them this idea 5 months ago. And explain why it would be a good idea. Looks like they listened lol 
I have cats see , so leather option wasn't good for me. And the creme looked nice but black is more my style (plus it'd be orange from doritos  in no time lol)
And the charcoal  with blue was an eye sore. 
Plus all the downsides of pu leather (sweating ,cracking,claws)
Anyone who works in an office area who wants a nice stylish chair would be laughed at with that blue. Its just to much of a niche color .It wouldn't even match my gaming setup. 
I told them after they said they weren't planning on at that time making anymore variations of the software. That they should make a neutral color softweave fabric like  all black /charcoal would be beneficial to the companies softweave brand due to the widespread of appeal of black being good for office,gaming and just about anywhere and that competitors aren't making fabric options. 
I laid out like 2 pages of reasoning why it would be good 
Idea for a neutral black scheme.
They thanked me and told me they would tell them.
  Now I'm sure others complained and ask as well. But it just seemed pretty coincidental that not to long after i suggested they did it. And I'm so glad I waited. I was gonna buy that charcoal blue and let a black permanent marker do it's magic lol but I sure didn't want to shell out 300 and make the chair look worse.
Its pretty sweet that a company actually  listen to its potential customers.

(P.s was gonna post my conversation  with omega labs about it but facebook either won't let me go back that far or internet sucks to bad to load)

NOTICE: Got my chair today, assembled it, sat in it, (Really firm chair btw,. Had hoped when purchasing it, it would have been softer. If you've sat in a Ferrari, Lambo, etc. and felt how firm the cushioning of the seats were,..then you have a good idea of what this chair feels like..).  But I digress, noone is mentioning that damn screw you have to remove from right side of the  chair that prevents the recline function from working. I almost ripped the damn lever off before realizing there was a screw there stopping it from moving. Just something to be aware of...Yeah I can hear it now, read the damn directions, but I watched the installation video from SL and didnt see a section on removing this bolt. Note fo SL,..Other than that, the quality and craftsmanship of these chairs are par none,..I almost dont want want to sit in it. I feel like I'm disrespecting Danny, lol. Remember the screw!!

comment: could of used someone with good posture to promote the chair tho :)

Can i adjust the armrest to fullest till its
Not in the way of me playing guitar?
comment_reply:
Hi, if you are worried that your armrests are in the way when you are playing the guitar, you can easily detach them by removing the M8 screws holding them in place. However, we advise against doing so as the armrests play a crucial role in supporting your wrists and elbows, which in turn helps take the strain off your neck and shoulders.

Our full-metal 4D armrests are fully adjustable in four different directions:
1. Up/down
2. Front/back
3. Sideways 
4. Diagonally 

We recommend that you try adjusting them to a position that best suits your preference and needs first. You can also check out their exact dimensions right here: https://secretlab.co/pages/resources We hope this helps!

comment: The seat was way too stiff even over time it never softened up. glad I sent I back and got a better chair that's actual quality

I bought the Titan 2 weeks ago. Can't wait to get rid of it. The seat is so uncomfortable plus the fact that there is a slight lip on the edge of the seat that it's causing my hamstrings to tense up. What makes it worse is that SecretLabs is asking me to pay for the shipping back for a refund. They are selling "premium" chairs so they shouldn't be asking for S&H costs. Perhaps the Omega might have been better, but the "ridges" on the edge of the seats and no lumbar support was an issue for me.

I debated on buying this chair for ONE year going through many reviews. Worst decision ever.

For context, I'm 5'10" tall, medium built, 155lbs. Here are the things wrong with this chair that are a deal breaker for me:

- Armrest is too far away to be comfortable.
- Armrest is too high even at it's lowest setting causing shoulders to be in an unnatural position.
- The chair is slightly high despite of being at its lowest setting. Perhaps if I was an inch taller that wouldn't be a problem.

FYI - here are the good things about it:

- Solid built especially the wheels.
- Texture and quality of the suede is good.
- Moving the chair around is very easy on my mat (carpet).
- Excellent lumbar support - by far the best.
- The headrest cushion is very good - though I don't use it.
- 90 degrees posture.
comment_reply: It sounds like they are right, you may be better suited for the Omega. I believe it is shorter, which would allow you to go lower to the ground, which would probably prevent the seat from hurting your hamstrings. Arm rests though? Yeah I'm a little worried about those.  I just bought the chair and I am fully prepared to return it if I don't love it. I however, did look at their return policy before making a purchase. How much did shipping end up costing?

comment: I can speak for the Omega and I will tell you the seat is rock hard. Its a very nice chair but uncomfortable as hell. I want to know why not one reviewer has said one thing about this?
comment_reply: I've seen more than 10 reviews for the Omega and Titan, and a lot of them do mention that. The reason for being so rock hard when it's brand new is because of durability, if it was really soft from the start it would eventually create kind of a hole on it and lose it's soft comfortability very quick. The seat will slowly give in over time and it will become more comfortable in a few weeks, depending on how much you use it. Being rock hard when it's new it's actually kind of a good thing.

comment_reply: UPDATE: I have been sitting in this chair for the last month normally for 3-4 hours at a time and I have found it very comfortable. In terms of headrest space, there is still ample room above my head (I'd say 2 inches depending how you're sitting) so those worried about their head going past the headrest shouldn't worry. In terms of the seat, it has no problem supporting my legs. This chair has a design meant to hug you into the seat, which it does but isn't restrictive, so don't expect to spread your legs apart for than a few inches on both sides.The backrest is not as constrictive though, giving plenty of room to shift around but also keeping you in the chair. Out of the box, the seat is fairly firm but it takes some time to break in the leather and find which position works best for you. If you are looking for a more "fitted" seating experience, go for the Omega, or if you prefer the larger bucket-style seats, then go for the Titan. Be aware, this chair is fairly stiff when it arrives, it took about a month on continuous use for the leather to start becoming more malleable.  Hope this was helpful

I bought the Titan 2020 just 2 weeks ago. Can't wait to get rid of it. The seat is so uncomfortable plus the fact that there is a slight lip on the edge of the seat that it's causing my hamstrings to tense up. What makes it worse is that SecretLabs is asking me to pay for the shipping back for a refund. They are selling "premium" chairs so they shouldn't be asking for S&H costs. Perhaps the Omega might have been better, but the "ridges" on the edge of the seats and no lumbar support was an issue for me. Perhaps the Omega might have been better, but the "ridges" on the edge of the seats and no lumbar support was an issue for me.

I debated on buying this chair for ONE year going through many reviews. Worst decision ever.

For context, I'm 5'10" tall, medium built, 155lbs. Here are the things wrong with this chair that are a deal breaker for me:

- Armrest is too far away to be comfortable.
- Armrest is too high even at it's lowest setting causing shoulders to be in an unnatural position.
- The chair is slightly high despite of being at its lowest setting. Perhaps if I was an inch taller that wouldn't be a problem.

FYI - here are the good things about it:

- Solid built especially the wheels.
- Texture and quality of the suede is good.
- Moving the chair around is very easy on my mat (carpet).
- Excellent lumbar support - by far the best.
- The headrest cushion is very good - though I don't use it.
- 90 degrees posture.

When AD made Right!

Can one of your chairs come in a dark brown instead of black? It is impossible to find a gaming chair that comes in a natural color. I believe there is a huge untapped market of a "gaming chair" that can fit inside of a home and look like it belongs. Now don't get me wrong, I think your chairs look sleek and cool, very expensive and stylish. I am only asking for the same sexy chair in a warm color with a more subtle logo on the back. We live in a generation where gamers are in their 30s and 40s and at some point, it's nice to live in a home that looks like one instead of something out of a college dorm. I love my husband and I don't think it's right to ask him to set up a "gaming room" away from the central location of our home just because a gaming chair looks extremely out of place. I would never do that. But it is also a pain to go through all the work, painting, planning, diy etc to make the place look and feel nice to immediately be neglegable when the chair brings your eye right to it as it obviously doesn't belong. Maybe this will start a war on the comments but I have been searching for years to find something that fits my desire for a "sweet homey" look and his gaming fantasy and my search has come up empty. 
Anybody else think this is something that they or their spouse would appreciate?

I have the chair (the old version) the armrests are the worst piece of garbage in the world and its a shame they are on this 400 dollar chair. The rest of the chair is fine, but the armrests are extremely loose and the cheap fake leather they use to cover it rips off quite easy.  I've already had to replace squeaky armrest.  Also be careful of the reviews of this chair, MANY of the reviews ive found on youtube are straight up paid reviews and are very biased. Secretlab also does not offer free returns, they keep 20 percent of what you paid and you have to pay for shipping to return it. Despite this secretlab has no chairs available at any locations i've found to actually test out before you buy it so you are stuck with this uncertainty even before you buy. Don't get me wrong, the chair is totally fine and if it werent for the armrests i would say it was almost worth the 430 bucks i paid. My problem with Secretlab is their shady advertising and their goal is to make money, not to make a good chair for a good price. Anybody considering buying a gaming chair, try to find a brand that actually lets you use the product commit to buying it, if you cant like i couldnt then at least listen to what i have to say about the damn chair.




The Titan is definitely built for comfort over long periods of sitting. It is not comfortable like a couch or recliner. Its not some soft padding that you can snuggle up in, its actually quite firm and it pushes on you. Only get this chair if you plan on sitting for long periods of time and dont want a sore ass.

comment:
Had once since 2018. Felt like like the price back then, still does now. Only wear and tear is the pillow (I use it as a tailbone support) and the armrests (wobbly as hell, but the 2020 version should've fixed that with metal ones). No PU leather shedding, only a wrinkle or two. I don't sweat often, it's in a nice cool, dark room most the time. Most complaints about this chair tear are from either south east Asia where there is humid weather with poor AC sometimes, or overly sweaty situations. In that case get a fabric chair (there is an option for this in Titan chairs). 

Being real here from chairs sat on at family/friends homes or in store, this is a good chair. Probably one of the best "gaming" chairs (stupid name). It's definitely worth the price ($389 back then) and I probably wouldn't say that if this was above $500. This chair isn't just a price and marketing, there is a good chair and really feels like it's priced correctly. I wouldn't call this a Herman Miller (fucking Christ they brainwashed people to thinking they're worth second hand for hundreds of $$$ after they've had asses buried in and farted all over for 24/5 in a week, no) but this is a good mid range chair that excels in style if nothing else. Other chair's in this price range i've seen have less adjustibility, style, or comfort. As an office chair I'd say above average compared to everything in it's price bracket. You don't have to worry about wasting money when getting it, but just make sure you like what you see. 

Worth price, Yes. Good style, absolutely. Durability, pretty reasonable I'd say. 4/5 for me, no more nor less.

I have one of these chairs and Adjustability is great, move the back, move the arms, up and down and etc. but your firmness doesn't do justice to just how stiff this chair is.........   A rock is a better term to use for describing it's comfort....  If you like sitting on a hardwood floor then this is the chair for you. A nice piece of foam or a good winter blanket between you and the chair will get you a little comfort you wanted in the first place.  Better yet save your money and try out some chairs at an office furniture store and get the one you like. You will be happy you did...  Oh, almost forgot, the softweave is Pilling after 7 months of use.

comment:
I have one which I use for working in my home office room.  For reference I'm 185cm height and 80kg weight.  

Fittings and mechanisms:  Solid quality feel and action, base is a sturdy die cast part so I'd hope this will last well and the swivel bearing in the seat base is smooth with little drag.  Fixing bolts are a robust size and everything feels secure once pushed or bolted together.  Tilt, lift and back rest angle adjustment are nice to operate and the lumbar adjuster has an indexed on the dial so you can feel when it's close to the end of the tension.  The arm-rests don't exhibit any play once latched into their designated position. 

Feel: They are unexpectedly firm straight from the box but I found that translates to good postural support for prolonged periods; combined with setting the monitor height correctly at my computer I work comfortably all day without feeling fatigue in my back or shoulders.  I don't tend to sit for more than 2hours at a time without getting up (usually to make coffee/tea etc.) so I can't comment on whether a numb butt would be present eventually.  The wrap round support on the back rest isn't that relevant to me due to my build but the general contour of the backrest is very good.  The relatively flat base is a benefit as you can sit in a more natural position with your knees apart as desired.  I opted for the soft weave which seems to breath and regulate temperature quite well.  I once owned  a PU leather jacket and it was like wearing cling film on a warm day hence I avoided the PU leather fabric for this chair just in case.

Adjustment:  Recline range is more than adequate for anyone and the separate base tilt with lock and tension adjuster helps you find the best position for your hips.  The 4D arm-rests are excellent, especially if you want to use them to rest your elbows on while typing or if you want to swing them round when using a mouse etc. The are a firm material but tactile enough for superb comfort.    

If I had one criticism I would ask for a few cm lower on the minimum height adjustment.  Principally due to the fact that when fully reclined with your legs hanging the base can feel a little firm in the back of the knees.  Given that the Omega only has 40mm lower back rest height I estimate that chair would still have fitted me and given me the cm or so lower minimum height.  However since the Titan has the integral lumbar adjuster instead of just a cushion it would still be my choice; after all the time I spend reclined is very small compared to the time I spend in and upright seated position at my desk.

I can't comment on longevity at the present time as I've owned mine for 2 months.  Secretlabs only offer the extended 5-year warranty if you do some social media sharing of your purchase, in effect doing some free marketing for them.  Personally I feel this is a bit of a pretentious requirement, if they really think the product is good enough to warrant it for 5 years then they should just provide that period rather than it being conditional on them receiving free advertising.   Even in these times not all of us want to share the privacy of our own space on social media and they should realise that providing a good quality product and standing by it is all the positive marketing they'll ever need.
Awesome review, are you still as happy with it now?

I've had the Titan 2020 for a few weeks now. It is a little overrated to be honest. Yes, very firm but you need a firm chair for a good posture. If you're seeking ultimate comfort, you would have to chip in a little more and buy a Lazy Boy chair usually $200 to $300 more than the Titan.

I'm 5'19" tall, and weigh around 350 lbs. My old desk chair was falling apart and quite uncomfortable and I decided a couple months ago to get the Titan XL softweave navy blue edition. This thing is a beast! Also you can use the box it comes in to house a homeless person for a few weeks. It's nearly that big (and QUTIE heavy!). Chair assembly was pretty straightforward. I love this chair, the only thing I wish is that the seat cushion was a tad softer. But to be honest I'm VERY happy so far with this chair and highly recommend any large/tall/both person to look into acquiring one of these. They're pricy, but worth it. comment_reply: @Ben Cad Yeah bit sad as the chair is FANTASTIC. The unboxing was the greatest experience and the quality is superb. But it looks like the guide arms/holes on the side of the backrest are slightly misaligned. So you can see it when the armrest on the left is further away then the right from the backrest. Then i stood up and looked downwards on the chair: definitely skew. I loosed the screws and tried to reinstall the backrest and there is some play - but not enough to straighten it up. I've contacted support so will update on their response. But if you take a gander at the first two reddit posts there are maybe 20+ guys since June having the exact same issue on the left side. Which basically ruins the ergonomics as well as the visual aesthetic. Puts a dampener on what was otherwise a 10/10 purchase. If they resolve: no worries. But it doesnt look like guys are getting a solid result if the reddit thread is anything to go by....

comment_reply: @Ben Cad One thing people fail to mention is the backrest on a lot of the chairs shipped out is skew. Simply search will show multiple instances on reddit where the left side is further back than the right (Spring side). I.e. the back rest isn't at a 90 degree angle to the base. I've just received one and this is the case. You'll find a few accounts of it on reddit. If you'd like to be as accurate as possible and help them stop doing this by drawing attention to it: it'd be an unbiased approach at the least! It seems to be in the latest batch - since June.

comment_reply: @Maxemore Its the hardest thing to describe. I think my when I sat on the chair in the video I think the first thing that came to my head was a padded kitchen/dining room chair for the first few seconds. Then you feel its more padded than that. The main thing is you wont sink into the chair like you're probably used to likely with your current chair. Otherwise I would describe it as Supportive and Firm. But, you have a good 15cm of padding underneath you. All I can say is personally, 6 months+ in now and I can still go on all day on this chair comfortably and it shows no signs of the padding wearing out and sinking. I hope that helps!

comment:
This chair has a counter-ergonomic design flaw. The seat has an incline up by the front edge. Combined with the firmness of the foam it really badly cuts into hamstrings (bottom part of thighs). This is more than uncomfortable and makes thighs sore and numb as it affects blood flow.
I had watched 5 reviews including this one before I ordered. So I knew the foam is firm. This actually suits me well. The size I chose is a good fit fort me too. But even with the chair set in the lowest to the ground and max tilt forward to reduce the thighs pressure as much as possible, it is hard to bear even over a short period of time.
I'm sending it back and am yet to see how much it is going to cost me.  It is really a puzzle how a chair which such an obvious flaw can have so many good reviews and none mentioning this issue. Wouldn't recommend it.
comment_reply: That‚Äôs a shame it‚Äôs not working out for you. I can‚Äôt say this has been an issue at all for me. I guess everyone is different! If you‚Äôve only just received the chair I‚Äôd recommend giving it a week or so to adjust. But if not, that‚Äôs a shame it‚Äôs not working for you! Good luck with the return if you go down that path.

comment: Definitely changed my aim for the PU leather to the Softweave for this chair--great review. Now my only sticking point is sizing. At 5'6" 130lbs I'm firmly in Omega sizing according to the site, but I like to sit cross-legged a lot and in my current chair (Corsair T3 Rush, one heck of a mistake) the bucket seat makes that position quite uncomfortable, so I'm worried about the same in the Omega. However, I feel like if I go with the Titan my weight won't break the seat in enough to feel soft and plush. Would you happen to have any insight on smaller people in the Titan?
comment_reply:
Hi there, I'm 5'5" and 150 pounds and I had this debate as well. I never got the chance to sit in the Omega, but I bought the Titan as I found a good deal on a used 2020 and I'm finding it very comfortable. I can sit cross-legged in it easily, and the height for the chair and the armrests goes down low enough for my feet to touch the floor. The back of knees is right at the end of the seat and I find it very comfortable.

I can't say how it compares to the Omega but I will say the Titan has a similar seat size to an average run-of-the-mill office chair. I find it quite comfortable, and I can move around in it easily - I think the Omega might have been too tight to accommodate my odd leg positions.

comment: Ben, after your review, I think I would definitely choose the Softweave option over the PU Leather. However, if one could afford the price of the NAPA Leather (supposedly REAL leather, unlike the PU Leather), would the NAPA leather be a better option than the Softweave in terms of comfort and durability?
comment_reply: You know, after owning the fabric material, I‚Äôm pretty happy with it, I think I prefer it over the leather styles materials. You don‚Äôt slide in it, it‚Äôs not cold when you first sit on it and it breathes. So I think I‚Äôd stick with my choice. For durability, well a few months on (with covid use) and it‚Äôs still looking just as good so far. Thankfully no spills or anything yet. For leather you will need to treat it and oil it etc. So it really comes down to maintenance, I‚Äôve seen leather furniture that looks great at 10/20 years and also some that‚Äôs aged horribly. Before committing to that price tag I would want to see how this chair I‚Äôm on lasts it‚Äôs really about the mechanical components, and this stage it‚Äôs going well. But at that price point the expectations are even bigger.

Nice video with nice information, one of the things that have kept me from pushing that BUY button is the fact that the seat is hard. I have read many reviews in regards to that. Me needing extra padding on the seat but soft at the same time, would you recommend this chair ? My tail bone hurts easily on a regular chair.
comment_reply: Thanks, yeah padding is I think the hardest thing to describe in videos, photo or text.  Its likely it will be firmer than what are you sitting on now, but also will likely be more supportive. So there is a chance (not that I would know) that it may help out your pain? Or then again it wont (sorry). When I got mine, it was firmer than what I was expecting but its totally fine for me now.  I will say this, in regards to tail-bone pain, I get that really bad in Aeroplane seats when travelling and I've never had anything like that with this chair. With COVID I'm frequently doing 12+ hours in the chair and have been pain free all day, every day. Secretlab do a have an info page on their site addressing the firmness concerns, it may help you. It comes with a learning curve and you'll need to adjust, and without a doubt I'm sure it wont be good for everyone. Committing to buy without a test-sit is definitely the hardest part, for me once I finally purchased that's when the Secretlab experience improved.

comment: nice vid mate, what is your opinion on all the negative reviews of these chairs?
comment_reply: Ah I dunno mate, I honestly think Secretlab may be going *too hard* with their marketing and its scaring people away, like it forced me to do too much research before buying. I mean is it the perfect chair? I doubt it, are chairs that are twice+ the price better than it? Probably. I think Secretlab are targeting the people like me who are coming from those $100-$300 chairs that only last a couple of years, and for that market, its a huge improvement. Otherwise, for aesthetics Secretlab nails it, I mean I don't want 1) Fluro Red/Blue/Pink etc stripes all over my chair and 2) I don't want an ergonomic office chair that's makes me feel like I'm sitting at my desk at the work office (even if they are comfier and cost double).  For the negative reviews, the biggest trend I found when researching were the comments on the firmness of the chair, and thats probably the hardest thing to explain in a written or video review, so I think its fair its a common complaint, particularly if the user is not an all day user who can appreciate the all-day comfort this chair seems to provide. Cheers

i bought a dx racer chair and it was a big mistake it worn out and i only had it for 1 year

I bought the omega and here's my two cents: ditch any gaming chair in general and go for an office chair. The wings on the back rest squeeze your shoulders and body together/forward, among other stupid design flaws. The chair has plenty of shiny adjustment options, but is designed with the intention that you will be sitting with perfect gaming posture all the time and that you will manually adjust the chair again every time you want to readjust your body position a bit. If you're a professional gamer, go for it. If you like to be comfortable, get an office chair. I regret my purchase, but I'm gonna take off the arm rests to see if it feels any better. My old $50 looking hand me down chair is waay more comfortable, only problem was the arm rests couldn't be adjusted.

comment:
I just ordered the same one today. I've had an IKEA Markus chair for several years now, and the hardness of the seat finally got to me, sitting in it for 12 hours a day now in average, between work from home as a software developer and gaming in the offtime.  

So since you mentioned you work with cars, how would you compare the fabric and seat support/comfort to fabric upholstered automotive seat?
comment_reply: Fabric is always a terrible choice especially for keeping clean and looking clean. Not to mention, if you're always in a chair because of work & gaming, why buy a stupid gaming chair? Invest in a proper ergonomic office chair to save your back. They're expensive but generally they have over a decade of warranty (which proves quality) and is worth the investment. I have shitty akracing gaming chair right now, god awful and sometimes i switch back to my shitty old ikea chair. But I ordered a new office chair for $1075+tax (got a 45% discount) and i know i wont regret it. All my friends work places have these expensive ergo desks and chairs, considering companies are cheap, you have to question why they would spend so much on an employee. Because there are good benefits to spending that money.

comment:

comment_reply: Hey Mitoni, interesting question on the car seats. I guess really I would say it feels similar to cloth material in cars. Thats the simple answer, but to be more in depth perhaps the material is a little rougher on the fingers compared to a standard car cloth seat material which I think is a little smoother - I would say car material needs to account for movement and friction more than an office chair. But overall pretty similar.  Obviously Alcantara would be the dream material to have :)

comment: I've had my Softweave Titan for 11 months now and have to say I'm 100% satisfied with it. Still looks as good as the day I unboxed it and is extremely comfortable. I like you was skeptical as to how much positive info was out there about Secret Labs but now after owning the Titan for almost a year can say it's well deserved. I spend at least 8 hours a day in my Titan and even though it's firm or possibly because it is it's the most comfortable computer chair I've ever owned. I'm 53 and disabled and prior to my Titan I was having to buy a new chair at a minimum of every 2 years. The way my Titan and it's fabric are holding up with minimal maintenance I fully expect it to last far longer. At first it seemed far to stiff to be as comfortable as it is but I can say it has truly helped with my back pain. They are however not cheap but if you figure in having to replace a cheaper chair much more often it balances out. The level of comfort is something else to consider with my Titan I never feel as badly after sitting for long periods as I did with cheaper chairs. Sorry for the TLDR post but I felt I should share my experience as well to maybe help others. I had my Titan in the cart for a good 2 months before I finally pulled the trigger. Honestly I wish I'd bought it sooner because believe it or not the hype is real...
good video, subscribed. cheers mate!

comment:
The thing with new chairs is they are always nice and quiet to start.  I have a base DX Racer, and when I replaced my old office chair, it was the same thing.  The old chair made heaps of noise and had loads of wobble because it was well used.  The DX Racer was new and not even broken in yet.  Fast forward around 3-4 years yes the DX Racer is still  holding up very well over all.  The leathery material in sections are starting to begin to flake, and there is a lot of noise when ever you get up, sit down, move in your chair on the hinge that allows the chair to lean back.  I sprayed some silicone lubricant on the hinge and it silenced it up and the chair felt brand new again, however only for a few weeks before it began making the same noise again.  They also don't make it so you can tear it down to give it a good cleaning, and proper lube it up.  Maybe the Secretlabs chair is different, I don't know. 


Over all yes the DX Racer I have, even though its the bog standard base model is still a good chair over all.  The foam is still firm, the chairs construction over all is very well done.  The arm rests and the squeaking are about the only 2 things I have a problem with.  The arm rests this one comes with are made of a pasticy, foamy, rubbery type of material.  They have begun to wear down in the areas there are the metal plates under for the actual support.  Again materials like that will be the first to break down, and it did take a good time to start to break down.  Though comfort overall isnt the best, a proper office chair will do anyone much better then some "gaming" chair.

comment: Hello Ben, thanks for your video. What would you suggest for a 179cm for 75kg guy  ? On one hand I'm scared about the fact that Omega would be too little, on the other hand that Titan would be too big! Thanks a lot for any suggestion you'll provide!
comment_reply: Similar dilemma I had, but you're a bit shorter only by a few cm. I would say either chair would do you fine. (keep in mind I've never physically touched an Omega chair), but I'd think about the fit your after, Omega is supposed to hug you in a bit more, The titan wont  hug at your size I'd say. You'll probably be happy either way. Think about if you want a pillow or proper lumbar support. I'd say the only thing you find a little annoying with Titan is the position of the pillow, at my height I do need to pull it down a little every few days to readjust it, I would say you would need to do the same with the Titan. Hope you make the right choice, I think you'll likely be happy either way,

comment: Fantastic review Ben ive made my decision on what chair to get and yes its the Titan, Thank you from the Uk.

On my chair the box was dropped and handled very badly by fedex (the box is really heavy, i have the titan and its about 78 ibs so when it dropped it seems it dropped hard), the left armrest came broken and i reached out to Secretlabs and WITHIN A WEEK had a brand new armrest shipped out to me free of charge EXTREMELY satisfied with their customer service speed and willingness to assist.

I have had my 2020 Titan for about a month and love it. Mine arrived in perfect condition was easy to assemble. The adjustable armrest are amazing and are a feature that don't get mentioned often in reviews that really make a difference in your overall comfort along with the lumbar support. My experience is the Titan is the perfect combination of support and pressure relief and no other gaming chair I have owned comes close in material & build quality.  Worth every dollar in my opinion.

comment: Realistically, how hard is the seat cushion? Could you compare it to something? And is it like you can feel.the supporting frame, or is it just very stiff? This is probably the only thing that is putting me off.
comment_reply: Hey Mase, it‚Äôs certainly the hardest part to describe in a video. First up, no it‚Äôs not like you feel the frame at all! It‚Äôs just generally the foam is a lot more firmer than you think (there‚Äôs a lot of foam there too). It‚Äôs certainly a lot more firm than the other 2 chairs I show you in the video. But, you don‚Äôt ‚Äòsink‚Äô into the chair, where you can feel you‚Äôve hit the frame or anything, it‚Äôs like the whole base is working to support you, and yes because of that it‚Äôs firmer. And that‚Äôs where it gets firm because this chair has kept me supported and comfortable all day.  I guess for the the VERY FIRST impression when I sat on it, in that first split second I compared the padding to a kitchen dining room chair, or a chair perhaps on public transport or an older school chair in a cinema, note I said padding not the chair. But only for that initial split second, I think you‚Äôll be happy with the chair but go in knowing it‚Äôs likely more firm than what you‚Äôre sitting on now, and you‚Äôll need a few days to adjust. After that you‚Äôll probably be happy with it. The chair is about all day comfort and not short term. I‚Äôm doing my best to describe it here, so don‚Äôt take my chair comparison here as a super serious comment cos I realize those chairs are likely negative descriptions to use, but I‚Äôm just trying think of similar padding. Secret lab also have a webpage talking about why the chairs are firm if you haven‚Äôt seen it.. they have a chart there which tries to describe how firm it is and they put it in between an executive office chair, and a wooden chair in terms of firmness. Which also is a hard pill to swallow lol.

comment_reply:
@Mushroomstamp my pleasure. 
The bolsters hit pressure points in my legs causing circulation and nerve problem. The foam is very firm and never loosens up. This is a good thing if you want a really really firm chair like a board, but if you expect the cushions to soften up over time, they do not. So it is just a very firm chair that causes incredible body fatigue over time. I have back and hip issues for the last year and I was hoping this chair would help but instead it has made it much worse due to an inconsistent lumbar support (being a memory foam pillow) and way to firm cushion and no ergonomics causing pressure point issues. It's hard for me to say because the chair is so dope looking and I love how it tilts, great arm rests etc. I've been in denial about how bad it has been for my body because I want to love the chair. This is specific to my issues but I know YouTube creators get good incentives from secretlab to not talk shit so there are VERY FEW people saying anything negative.

comment: I cant decide if, I should go with secretlab chair fabric or just go with office chair. I wanna know the base sit if its soft and not hot to sit on because I live in Asia and its hot here and I dont have air condition room.
comment_reply: International DC Well to put it simply, Secretlab uses a cold cure foam while other brands use typical foams. Cold cure is way better in the sense that no matter how long you sit in the chair, itll never fully go down thus making it comfier because it doesn‚Äôt squish down having you sit on the base of the chair (Like most manufacturers make it.) Once you get up the foam goes back to its original shape so overall its not as soft as a cheap office chair will be but will be way comfier while sitting in it for long periods of time. The cloth material also allows breathability while the PU or Leather editions retain heat. Since its a high quality cloth it doesn‚Äôt allow you to get nearly as hot or sweaty as other chairs and I personally think its the best chair I‚Äôve ever sat in. Definitely worth the price especially with the 2020 edition having lots of upgrades compared to the 2018 models. Yes its a high price point but you‚Äôre paying for quality and these chairs are definitely built to last.

At about 9 months of normal use a sharp metal piece is sticking out of the cushion and stabs the back of my leg. I bought my wife a procduct display, normal office computer chair for $100. That chair is 10x better and more comfortable than my $500 Titan chair.
Only pro is it looks nice from a far and came is a fancy box.
Do not buy.
comment_reply: So you spent all that money, and rather than getting it fixed for free, you just moan about it online.  Yeah right.... You never actually had one did you?

comment: Greetings from Finland! Thanks man for these great videos! You made me to make the purchase for one of these. Now have an omega on the way. Most of them are leather/PU-leather ones. Keep up the good work dude!

Chairs in Canada cost even more. A $450-1500 office chair in the US can be $700-2000 here lol. Alot of office chairs are poorly packaged so they are damaged on arrival and they can be really bad quality too, even from brands like Herman Miller. I have only seen 1 or 2 ugly, but decent ones under $500. But the PU leather on my last 2 chairs peeled off in 1-1.5 years so I'm hopeful but skeptical of secretlab still. You rarely get what you pay for. Might just try secret lab anyway, there doesn't seem to be anything else worth it.

I'm a not happy owner of one of these god awful chairs, just got my stark chair a little over a week ago and it's a beautiful work of art. If you are shopping for a gaming chair and considering your options... look no further.
The ONLY consideration I might add is that if you prefer a slightly larger chair and/or one with an integrated lumbar support you might consider the Secretlab Titan which is also an amazing chair.

comment_reply:
@Captain I Win - for $120 its not horrible. If you are on a super tight budget I would recommend it more than some others (Homall, Vitesse, Ficmax, etc) Putting it together was easy. But it wasn't very comfortable, especially after more than an hour or two of sitting in it. The pads were very thin and you could feel the bands (not metal) that held the weight through the padding. Pillows were as you would expect. Lumbar pillow was basically useless, but it did include straps to keep it in place.
Secretlab is definitely worth the extra money... but understandably some people dont have $350 for a gaming chair.

Hi mate, I own the black and gold titan and me being 6.0 foot on the dot is perfect for me. When I look at you in it, I'm sorry to say you're too big for it. 

You fit the Titan XL perfectly on the other hand. Maybe the feeling of being held in isn't going to end up being the best as the normal titan over time will begin to feel cramped, where the XL will begin to feel perfect in the long run.

It's like for myself the Omega to the titan. 

I'm so glad I ended up with the titan in the end, I've had mine for 3 1/2 years now and it is just perfect! 

If I had the omega I wouldn't be saying that. 

The Titan XL is actually the right chair for you sorry to say. 

Look at the video and look at yourself on the Titan, you can't see it at all. The Titan XL fits your dimensions perfectly when you're sitting on it by comparison. 

If you're also a bobsledder that's why I'm sure you like the song fit, but the titan simply isn't big enough for you the Titan XL is perfect instead. 

Keep the Titan XL, trust a Titan owner!

comment: You think the Titan could hold 150 kg or 330 lb only listen to 90 and I'm assuming that whatever they list it can hold a little bit more so if you're 300 I doubt it that makes any difference but let's say you were 3:30 and therefore when that case 40 lb over the the recommended weight limit what do you think would happen to the Titan
comment_reply:
@TheAxelBrown Sitting in most office chairs which list 250 to 275 I don't see them instantly breaking and honestly, like the Neuechair why they don't just make it rated for 330 like the Triigger, its direct competitor I can't fathom why they list at 240, yet say someone is 260 or 275 I don't think these chairs will break if going over slightly, and for the Titan/Omega I'd assume that 50 lbs might even be a good guestimation on a true 'max weight', plus it stats on their site: RECOMMENDED weight, not maximum.


But then I see in reviews people lay all the way back and even try and lean back and rock it a little and they don't fall back so these chairs seem extremely stable and would take great weight or effort to tip over.


Then I thought, if the Titan is made for a medium to large and the Titan XL is made for L to XL size, but their is a recommended weight difference, but the other dimensions are probably more fitting for someone, who is, say 5"10 rather than 6'0+ on the Titan as far as seat, length of distance for legs to touch the floor, and sure if you have a wide ass girth then clearly the XL is the way to go but for husky guys who simply weigh more, but are smaller frame than someone like you are who is clearly tall and larger frame, that the Titan might be a better option. Of course the XL works too and the real benefit is you know the weight won't be an problem but things like does the head rest line up with your head height since if you were not 6'5" to 6"10" would it be and thus the Titan might accomodate that more.


Personally, the Titan should have been designed with a 330 or 350 lb max weight, or 'recommended' 300 and max 350 or something like that, and then the XL made for the heavier frame 400 recommended, 450 max. Then make the XL cost appropriately more, but what your getting is the extra weight limit and height limit and for those who truly need it they can select this. I also don't like the way the XL lacks all the cool cosmetic choices.


Honestly if Midnight Blue or Graphite Blue in NAPA with, say, black swede trim, would have been available in Titan, or even Titan XL that would be the way I'd go personally. Yet, I really ilked the Omega with the Black Suede Trim, and like the Omega symbol more than the T on the Titan, but the trim on the Stealth is great trim. They seemed to dial back the NAPA leather options though.

comment: You think the Titan could hold 150 kg or 330 lb only listen to 90 and I'm assuming that whatever they list it can hold a little bit more so if you're 300 I doubt it that makes any difference but let's say you were 3:30 and therefore when that case 40 lb over the the recommended weight limit what do you think would happen to the Titan
comment_reply:
So, obviously i cant recommend going over the limit, in case there is a safety issue. All i can say is that I've sat on the titan with someone sat on my lap and had no issues, but that wasn't for too long. So its difficult to say what the long term implications would be. How come not just go for the XL and be sure? 

If i had to wager, and again this is not official info, but i would say the weight guideline on the site is there more as a size guideline than the actual weight limit of the chair. I didn't notice any reinforcements or anything different when building the XL. Hope that helps! :)

comment:
Hey, i just got my chair 2 days ago, just wanted to ask if yours had a chemical smell? If it did how long did it last? I'm just a bit paranoid that 
it might be a toxic batch or something haha..
comment_reply: Project: Jericho The thing is it isn‚Äôt bonded leather, the chair I got was the fabric version. The heat in California was intense last week and my room did not have ventilation. I sat and slept next to the chair for 3 days as I worked from home and I had no idea what off gassing was until I started having severe symptoms with breathing issues and now chest/lung pain. My dog wouldn‚Äôt even enter the room after I built the chair. It wasn‚Äôt until the 4th day when I moved the chair to the yard and the 5th day when I began to try to ventilate the room. I can‚Äôt even stay in that room anymore without having breathing issues. Now I‚Äôm wondering if the off gassing and poor ventilation  built up enough fumes to a point where it was at a toxicity level high enough to cause permanent damage to my lungs since I already have athsma. I honestly don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs because i am sensitive to off gassing, or if the chair was able to produce a dangerous enough amount due to the heat/poor ventilation in the room to harm me. Either way, I guess my question would be to you, am I now going to get cancer, or do chairs like these not produce enough fumes to cause cancer compared to say a worker that would be at risk to these raw chemicals.

comment:
Hey, i just got my chair 2 days ago, just wanted to ask if yours had a chemical smell? If it did how long did it last? I'm just a bit paranoid that 
it might be a toxic batch or something haha..
comment_reply: The entire product is one large petrochemical assembly... Of course it's going to outgas - how could it possibly not?  Heads up, bonded leather is ground-up tiny bits of leather scrap suspended in a polyurethane matrix. It's not leather - it's just a fancy plastic fabric.  As for the toxicity?  Yeah, it probably is to some degree... Just like any number of things we surround ourselves with.  If you own a shirt made of acrylic fabric - you're way more impacted by that than this chair; just don't eat the foam and you should be fine.

comment_reply: @Maggie Cao There is a comfortable amount of room for sitting cross-legged. The sides are also cushioned just enough so that it doesn't hurt or feel like you're sitting awkwardly when you do. The only thing that might be an issue maybe is your toes having to be curled if you sit this way for a long period of time. They'll dig in to the sides a bit. (I usually take it as my cue to go back to sitting properly, lol) As for the lumbar cushion, it's held up very nicely so far! I don't mind it being its own separate pillow because I find it easily adjustable. And it's my first chair with that kind of support, so for my first, it's not bad, lol.

As an owner of a Herman Miller Mirra chair since 2009 (and still rock-steady today), I've always wondered what's the actual value of gaming chairs other than their styles.
Beginning this year, that question got answered when I bought a Secret Lab Throne (am a tiny boy). The immediate difference is that I can rest my neck and head while leaning back, which actually affords me an extra level of relaxation unachievable on the Mirra (but I sit on that for work). Which makes me slightly calmer while gaming.

Secret Lab's lumbar cushion however could do with some velcro straps to hold it in place instead of falling off every time I lean forward or walk away.
